Laid bare a meaning twisted, deep and strange,\nl
The bizarre secret of their fumbling speech,\nl
Their links with underlying reality.\nl
The unseen grew visible and audible:\nl
Thoughts leaped down from a superconscient field\nl
Like eagles swooping from a viewless peak,\nl
Thoughts gleamed up from the screened subliminal depths\nl
Like golden fishes from a hidden sea.\nl
This world is a vast unbroken totality,\nl
A deep solidarity joins its contrary powers;\nl
God's summits look back on the mute Abyss.\nl
So man evolving to divinest heights\nl
Colloques still with the animal and the Djinn;\nl
The human godhead with star-gazer eyes\nl
Lives still in one house with the primal beast.\nl
The high meets the low, all is a single plan.\nl
So she beheld the many births of thought,\nl
If births can be of what eternal is;\nl
For the Eternal's powers are like himself,\nl
Timeless in the Timeless, in Time ever born.\nl
This too she saw that all in outer mind\nl
Is made, not born, a product perishable,\nl
Forged in the body's factory by earth-force.\nl
This mind is a dynamic small machine\nl
Producing ceaselessly, till it wears out,\nl
Page 541

With raw material drawn from the outside world,\nl
The patterns sketched out by an artist God.\nl
Often our thoughts are finished cosmic wares\nl
Admitted by a silent office gate\nl
And passed through the subconscient's galleries,\nl
Then issued in Time's mart as private make.\nl
For now they bear the living person's stamp;\nl
A trick, a special hue claims them his own.\nl
All else is Nature's craft and this too hers.\nl
Our tasks are given, we are but instruments;\nl
Nothing is all our own that we create:\nl
The Power that acts in us is not our force.\nl
The genius too receives from some high fount\nl
Concealed in a supernal secrecy\nl
The work that gives him an immortal name.\nl
The word, the form, the charm, the glory and grace\nl
Are missioned sparks from a stupendous Fire;\nl
A sample from the laboratory of God\nl
Of which he holds the patent upon earth,\nl
Comes to him wrapped in golden coverings;\nl
He listens for Inspiration's postman knock\nl
And takes delivery of the priceless gift\nl
A little spoilt by the receiver mind\nl
Or mixed with the manufacture of his brain;\nl
When least defaced, then is it most divine.\nl
Although his ego claims the world for its use,\nl
Man is a dynamo for the cosmic work;\nl
Nature does most in him, God the high rest:\nl
Only his soul's acceptance is his own.\nl
This independent, once a power supreme,\nl
Self-born before the universe was made,\nl
Accepting cosmos, binds himself Nature's serf\nl
Till he becomes her freedman—or God's slave.\nl
This is the appearance in our mortal front;\nl
Our greater truth of being lies behind:\nl
Our consciousness is cosmic and immense,\nl
Page 542

But only when we break through Matter's wall\nl
In that spiritual vastness can we stand\nl
Where we can live the masters of our world\nl
And mind is only a means and body a tool.\nl
For above the birth of body and of thought\nl
Our spirit's truth lives in the naked self\nl
And from that height, unbound, surveys the world.\nl
Out of the mind she rose to escape its law\nl
That it might sleep in some deep shadow of self\nl
Or fall silent in the silence of the Unseen.\nl
High she attained and stood from Nature free\nl
And saw creation's life from far above,\nl
Thence upon all she laid her sovereign will\nl
To dedicate it to God's timeless calm:\nl
Then all grew tranquil in her being's space,\nl
Only sometimes small thoughts arose and fell\nl
Like quiet waves upon a silent sea\nl
Or ripples passing over a lonely pool\nl
When a stray stone disturbs its dreaming rest.\nl
Yet the mind's factory had ceased to work,\nl
There was no sound of the dynamo's throb,\nl
There came no call from the still fields of life.\nl
Then even those stirrings rose in her no more;\nl
Her mind now seemed like a vast empty room\nl
Or like a peaceful landscape without sound.\nl
This men call quietude and prize as peace.\nl
But to her deeper sight all yet was there,\nl
Effervescing like a chaos under a lid;\nl
Feelings and thoughts cried out for word and act\nl
But found no response in the silenced brain:\nl
All was suppressed but nothing yet expunged;\nl
At every moment might explosion come.\nl
Then this too paused; the body seemed a stone.\nl
All now was a wide mighty vacancy,\nl
But still excluded from eternity's hush;\nl
For still was far the repose of the Absolute\nl
Page 543

And the ocean silence of Infinity.\nl
Even now some thoughts could cross her solitude;\nl
These surged not from the depths or from within\nl
Cast up from formlessness to seek a form,\nl
Spoke not the body's need nor voiced life's call.\nl
These seemed not born nor made in human Time:\nl
Children of cosmic Nature from a far world,\nl
Idea's shapes in complete armour of words\nl
Posted like travellers in an alien space.\nl
Out of some far expanse they seemed to come\nl
As if carried on vast wings like large white sails,\nl
And with easy access reached the inner ear\nl
As though they used a natural privileged right\nl
To the high royal entries of the soul.\nl
As yet their path lay deep-concealed in light.\nl
Then looking to know whence the intruders came\nl
She saw a spiritual immensity\nl
Pervading and encompassing the world-space\nl
As ether our transparent tangible air,\nl
And through it sailing tranquilly a thought.\nl
As smoothly glides a ship nearing its port,\nl
Ignorant of embargo and blockade,\nl
Confident of entrance and the visa's seal,\nl
It came to the silent city of the brain\nl
Towards its accustomed and expectant quay,\nl
But met a barring will, a blow of Force\nl
And sank vanishing in the immensity.\nl
After a long vacant pause another appeared\nl
And others one by one suddenly emerged,\nl
Mind's unexpected visitors from the Unseen\nl
Like far-off sails upon a lonely sea.\nl
But soon that commerce failed, none reached mind's coast.\nl
Then all grew still, nothing moved any more:\nl
Immobile, self-rapt, timeless, solitary\nl
A silent spirit pervaded silent Space.\nl
Page 544

\spar In that absolute stillness bare and formidable\nl
There was glimpsed an all-negating Void Supreme\nl
That claimed its mystic Nihil's sovereign right\nl
To cancel Nature and deny the soul.\nl
Even the nude sense of self grew pale and thin:\nl
Impersonal, signless, featureless, void of forms\nl
A blank pure consciousness had replaced the mind.\nl
Her spirit seemed the substance of a name,\nl
The world a pictured symbol drawn on self,\nl
A dream of images, a dream of sounds\nl
Built up the semblance of a universe\nl
Or lent to spirit the appearance of a world.\nl
This was self-seeing; in that intolerant hush\nl
No notion and no concept could take shape,\nl
There was no sense to frame the figure of things,\nl
A sheer self-sight was there, no thought arose.\nl
Emotion slept deep down in the still heart\nl
Or lay buried in a cemetery of peace:\nl
All feelings seemed quiescent, calm or dead,\nl
As if the heart-strings rent could work no more\nl
And joy and grief could never rise again.\nl
The heart beat on with an unconscious rhythm\nl
But no response came from it and no cry.\nl
Vain was the provocation of events;\nl
Nothing within answered an outside touch,\nl
No nerve was stirred and no reaction rose.\nl
Yet still her body saw and moved and spoke;\nl
It understood without the aid of thought,\nl
It said whatever needed to be said,\nl
It did whatever needed to be done.\nl
There was no person there behind the act,\nl
No mind that chose or passed the fitting word:\nl
All wrought like an unerring apt machine.\nl
As if continuing old habitual turns,\nl
And pushed by an old unexhausted force\nl
The engine did the work for which it was made:\nl
Page 545

Her consciousness looked on and took no part;\nl
All it upheld, in nothing had a share.\nl
There was no strong initiator will;\nl
An incoherence crossing a firm void\nl
Slipped into an order of related chance.\nl
A pure perception was the only power\nl
That stood behind her action and her sight.\nl
If that retired, all objects would be extinct,\nl
Her private universe would cease to be,\nl
The house she had built with bricks of thought and sense\nl
In the beginning after the birth of Space.\nl
This seeing was identical with the seen;\nl
It knew without knowledge all that could be known,\nl
It saw impartially the world go by,\nl
But in the same supine unmoving glance\nl
Saw too its abysmal unreality.\nl
It watched the figure of the cosmic game,\nl
But the thought and inner life in forms seemed dead,\nl
Abolished by her own collapse of thought:\nl
A hollow physical shell persisted still.\nl
All seemed a brilliant shadow of itself,\nl
A cosmic film of scenes and images:\nl
The enduring mass and outline of the hills\nl
Was a design sketched on a silent mind\nl
And held to a tremulous false solidity\nl
By constant beats of visionary sight.\nl
The forest with its emerald multitudes\nl
Clothed with its show of hues vague empty Space,\nl
A painting's colours hiding a surface void\nl
That flickered upon dissolution's edge;\nl
The blue heavens, an illusion of the eyes,\nl
Roofed in the mind's illusion of a world.\nl
The men who walked beneath an unreal sky\nl
Seemed mobile puppets out of cardboard cut\nl
And pushed by unseen hands across the soil\nl
Or moving pictures upon Fancy's film:\nl
Page 546

There was no soul within, no power of life.\nl
The brain's vibrations that appear like thought,\nl
The nerve's brief answer to each contact's knock,\nl
The heart's quiverings felt as joy and grief and love\nl
Were twitchings of the body, their seeming self,\nl
That body forged from atoms and from gas\nl
A manufactured lie of Maya's make,\nl
Its life a dream seen by the sleeping Void.\nl
The animals lone or trooping through the glades\nl
Fled like a passing vision of beauty and grace\nl
Imagined by some all-creating Eye.\nl
Yet something was there behind the fading scene;\nl
Wherever she turned, at whatsoever she looked,\nl
It was perceived, yet hid from mind and sight.\nl
The One only real shut itself from Space\nl
And stood aloof from the idea of Time.\nl
Its truth escaped from shape and line and hue.\nl
All else grew unsubstantial, self-annulled,\nl
This only everlasting seemed and true,\nl
Yet nowhere dwelt, it was outside the hours.\nl
This only could justify the labour of sight,\nl
But sight could not define for it a form;\nl
This only could appease the unsatisfied ear\nl
But hearing listened in vain for a missing sound;\nl
This answered not the sense, called not to Mind.\nl
It met her as the uncaught inaudible Voice\nl
That speaks for ever from the Unknowable.\nl
It met her like an omnipresent point\nl
Pure of dimensions, unfixed, invisible,\nl
The single oneness of its multiplied beat\nl
Accentuating its sole eternity.\nl
It faced her as some vast Nought's immensity,\nl
An endless No to all that seems to be,\nl
An endless Yes to things ever unconceived\nl
And all that is unimagined and unthought,\nl
An eternal zero or untotalled Aught,\nl
Page 547

A spaceless and a placeless Infinite.\nl
Yet eternity and infinity seemed but words\nl
Vainly affixed by mind's incompetence\nl
To its stupendous lone reality.\nl
The world is but a spark-burst from its light,\nl
All moments flashes from its Timelessness,\nl
All objects glimmerings of the Bodiless\nl
That disappear from Mind when That is seen.\nl
It held, as if a shield before its face,\nl
A consciousness that saw without a seer,\nl
The Truth where knowledge is not nor knower nor known,\nl
The Love enamoured of its own delight\nl
In which the Lover is not nor the Beloved\nl
Bringing their personal passion into the Vast,\nl
The Force omnipotent in quietude,\nl
The Bliss that none can ever hope to taste.\nl
It cancelled the convincing cheat of self;\nl
A truth in nothingness was its mighty clue.\nl
If all existence could renounce to be\nl
And Being take refuge in Non-being's arms\nl
And Non-being could strike out its ciphered round,\nl
Some lustre of that Reality might appear.\nl
A formless liberation came on her.\nl
Once sepulchred alive in brain and flesh\nl
She had risen up from body, mind and life;\nl
She was no more a Person in a world,\nl
She had escaped into infinity.\nl
What once had been herself had disappeared;\nl
There was no frame of things, no figure of soul.\nl
A refugee from the domain of sense,\nl
Evading the necessity of thought,\nl
Delivered from Knowledge and from Ignorance\nl
And rescued from the true and the untrue,\nl
She shared the Superconscient's high retreat\nl
Beyond the self-born Word, the nude Idea,\nl
The first bare solid ground of consciousness;\nl
Page 548

Beings were not there, existence had no place,\nl
There was no temptation of the joy to be.\nl
Unutterably effaced, no one and null,\nl
A vanishing vestige like a violet trace,\nl
A faint record merely of a self now past,\nl
She was a point in the unknowable.\nl
Only some last annulment now remained,\nl
Annihilation's vague indefinable step:\nl
A memory of being still was there\nl
And kept her separate from nothingness:\nl
She was in That but still became not That.\nl
This shadow of herself so close to nought\nl
Could be again self's point d'appui to live,\nl
Return out of the Inconceivable\nl
And be what some mysterious vast might choose.\nl
Even as the Unknowable decreed,\nl
She might be nought or new-become the All,\nl
Or if the omnipotent Nihil took a shape\nl
Emerge as someone and redeem the world.\nl
Even, she might learn what the mystic cipher held,\nl
This seeming exit or closed end of all\nl
Could be a blind tenebrous passage screened from sight,\nl
Her state the eclipsing shell of a darkened sun\nl
On its secret way to the Ineffable.\nl
Even now her splendid being might flame back\nl
Out of the silence and the nullity,\nl
A gleaming portion of the All-Wonderful,\nl
A power of some all-affirming Absolute,\nl
A shining mirror of the eternal Truth\nl
To show to the One-in-all its manifest face,\nl
To the souls of men their deep identity.\nl
Or she might wake into God's quietude\nl
Beyond the cosmic day and cosmic night\nl
And rest appeased in his white eternity.\nl
But this was now unreal or remote\nl
Or covered in the mystic fathomless blank.\nl
Page 549

In infinite Nothingness was the ultimate sign\nl
Or else the Real was the Unknowable.\nl
A lonely Absolute negated all:\nl
It effaced the ignorant world from its solitude\nl
And drowned the soul in its everlasting peace.\nl
\rl{\fsc End of Canto Six}
Page 550

\par
\ht Canto Seven: The Discovery of the Cosmic Spirit and the Cosmic Consciousness
\par
\sbigcap In the little hermitage in the forest's heart,\nl
In the sunlight and the moonlight and the dark\nl
The daily human life went plodding on\nl
Even as before with its small unchanging works\nl
And its spare outward body of routine\nl
And happy quiet of ascetic peace.\nl
The old beauty smiled of the terrestrial scene;\nl
She too was her old gracious self to men.\nl
The Ancient Mother clutched her child to her breast\nl
Pressing her close in her environing arms,\nl
As if earth ever the same could for ever keep\nl
The living spirit and body in her clasp,\nl
As if death were not there nor end nor change.\nl
Accustomed only to read outward signs\nl
None saw aught new in her, none divined her state;\nl
They saw a person where was only God's vast,\nl
A still being or a mighty nothingness.\nl
To all she was the same perfect Savitri:\nl
A greatness and a sweetness and a light\nl
Poured out from her upon her little world.\nl
Life showed to all the same familiar face,\nl
Her acts followed the old unaltered round,\nl
She spoke the words that she was wont to speak\nl
And did the things that she had always done.\nl
Her eyes looked out on earth's unchanging face,\nl
Around her soul's muteness all moved as of old;\nl
A vacant consciousness watched from within,\nl
Empty of all but bare Reality.\nl
There was no will behind the word and act,\nl
No thought formed in her brain to guide the speech:\nl
Page 551

An impersonal emptiness walked and spoke in her,\nl
Something perhaps unfelt, unseen, unknown\nl
Guarded the body for its future work,\nl
Or Nature moved in her old stream of force.\nl
Perhaps she bore made conscious in her breast\nl
The miraculous Nihil, origin of our souls\nl
And source and sum of the vast world's events,\nl
The womb and grave of thought, a cipher of God,\nl
A zero circle of being's totality.\nl
It used her speech and acted in her acts,\nl
It was beauty in her limbs, life in her breath;\nl
The original Mystery wore her human face.\nl
Thus was she lost within to separate self;\nl
Her mortal ego perished in God's night.\nl
Only a body was left, the ego's shell\nl
Afloat mid drift and foam of the world-sea,\nl
A sea of dream watched by a motionless sense\nl
In a figure of unreal reality.\nl
An impersonal foresight could already see,—\nl
In the unthinking knowledge of the spirit\nl
Even now it seemed nigh done, inevitable,—\nl
The individual die, the cosmos pass;\nl
These gone, the transcendental grew a myth,\nl
The Holy Ghost without the Father and Son,\nl
Or, a substratum of what once had been,\nl
Being that never willed to bear a world\nl
Restored to its original loneliness,\nl
Impassive, sole, silent, intangible.\nl
Yet all was not extinct in this deep loss;\nl
The being travelled not towards nothingness.\nl
There was some high surpassing Secrecy,\nl
And when she sat alone with Satyavan,\nl
Her moveless mind with his that searched and strove,\nl
In the hush of the profound and intimate night\nl
She turned to the face of a veiled voiceless Truth\nl
Hid in the dumb recesses of the heart\nl
Page 552

Or waiting beyond the last peak climbed by Thought,—\nl
Unseen itself it sees the struggling world\nl
And prompts our quest, but cares not to be found,—\nl
Out of that distant Vast came a reply.\nl
Something unknown, unreached, inscrutable\nl
Sent down the messages of its bodiless Light,\nl
Cast lightning flashes of a thought not ours\nl
Crossing the immobile silence of her mind:\nl
In its might of irresponsible sovereignty\nl
It seized on speech to give those flamings shape,\nl
Made beat the heart of wisdom in a word\nl
And spoke immortal things through mortal lips.\nl
Or, listening to the sages of the woods,\nl
In question and in answer broke from her\nl
High strange revealings impossible to men,\nl
Something or someone secret and remote\nl
Took hold of her body for his mystic use,\nl
Her mouth was seized to channel ineffable truths,\nl
Knowledge unthinkable found an utterance.\nl
Astonished by a new enlightenment,\nl
Invaded by a streak of the Absolute,\nl
They marvelled at her, for she seemed to know\nl
What they had only glimpsed at times afar.\nl
These thoughts were formed not in her listening brain,\nl
Her vacant heart was like a stringless harp;\nl
Impassive the body claimed not its own voice,\nl
But let the luminous greatness through it pass.\nl
A dual Power at being's occult poles\nl
Still acted, nameless and invisible:\nl
Her divine emptiness was their instrument.\nl
Inconscient Nature dealt with the world it had made,\nl
And using still the body's instruments\nl
Slipped through the conscious void she had become;\nl
The superconscient Mystery through that Void\nl
Missioned its word to touch the thoughts of men.\nl
As yet this great impersonal speech was rare.\nl
Page 553

But now the unmoving wide spiritual space\nl
In which her mind survived tranquil and bare,\nl
Admitted a traveller from the cosmic breadths:\nl
A thought came through draped as an outer voice.\nl
It called not for the witness of the mind,\nl
It spoke not to the hushed receiving heart;\nl
It came direct to the pure perception's seat,\nl
An only centre now of consciousness,\nl
If centre could be where all seemed only space;\nl
No more shut in by body's walls and gates\nl
Her being, a circle without circumference,\nl
Already now surpassed all cosmic bounds\nl
And more and more spread into infinity.\nl
This being was its own unbounded world,\nl
A world without form or feature or circumstance;\nl
It had no ground, no wall, no roof of thought,\nl
Yet saw itself and looked on all around\nl
In a silence motionless and illimitable.\nl
There was no person there, no centred mind,\nl
No seat of feeling on which beat events\nl
Or objects wrought and shaped reaction's stress.\nl
There was no motion in this inner world,\nl
All was a still and even infinity.\nl
In her the Unseen, the Unknown waited his hour.\nl

\spar But now she sat by sleeping Satyavan,\nl
Awake within, and the enormous Night\nl
Surrounded her with the Unknowable's vast.\nl
A voice began to speak from her own heart\nl
That was not hers, yet mastered thought and sense.\nl
As it spoke all changed within her and without;\nl
All was, all lived; she felt all being one;\nl
The world of unreality ceased to be:\nl
There was no more a universe built by mind,\nl
Convicted as a structure or a sign;\nl
A spirit, a being saw created things\nl
Page 554

And cast itself into unnumbered forms\nl
And was what it saw and made; all now became\nl
An evidence of one stupendous truth,\nl
A Truth in which negation had no place,\nl
A being and a living consciousness,\nl
A stark and absolute Reality.\nl
There the unreal could not find a place,\nl
The sense of unreality was slain:\nl
There all was conscious, made of the Infinite,\nl
All had a substance of Eternity.\nl
Yet this was the same Indecipherable;\nl
It seemed to cast from it universe like a dream\nl
Vanishing for ever into an original Void.\nl
But this was no more some vague ubiquitous point\nl
Or a cipher of vastness in unreal Nought.\nl
It was the same but now no more seemed far\nl
To the living clasp of her recovered soul.\nl
It was her self, it was the self of all,\nl
It was the reality of existing things,\nl
It was the consciousness of all that lived\nl
And felt and saw; it was Timelessness and Time,\nl
It was the Bliss of formlessness and form.\nl
It was all Love and the one Beloved's arms,\nl
It was sight and thought in one all-seeing Mind,\nl
It was joy of Being on the peaks of God.\nl
She passed beyond Time into eternity,\nl
Slipped out of space and became the Infinite;\nl
Her being rose into unreachable heights\nl
And found no end of its journey in the Self.\nl
It plunged into the unfathomable deeps\nl
And found no end to the silent mystery\nl
That held all world within one lonely breast,\nl
Yet harboured all creation's multitudes.\nl
She was all vastness and one measureless point,\nl
She was a height beyond heights, a depth beyond depths,\nl
She lived in the everlasting and was all\nl
Page 555

That harbours death and bears the wheeling hours.\nl
All contraries were true in one huge spirit\nl
Surpassing measure, change and circumstance.\nl
An individual, one with cosmic self\nl
In the heart of the Transcendent's miracle\nl
And the secret of World-personality\nl
Was the creator and the lord of all.\nl
Mind was a single innumerable look\nl
Upon himself and all that he became.\nl
Life was his drama and the Vast a stage,\nl
The universe was his body, God its soul.\nl
All was one single immense reality,\nl
All its innumerable phenomenon.\nl
\sparn Her spirit saw the world as living God;\nl
It saw the One and knew that all was He.\nl
She knew him as the Absolute's self-space,\nl
One with her self and ground of all things here\nl
In which the world wanders seeking for the Truth\nl
Guarded behind its face of ignorance:\nl
She followed him through the march of endless Time.\nl
All Nature's happenings were events in her,\nl
The heart-beats of the cosmos were her own,\nl
All beings thought and felt and moved in her;\nl
She inhabited the vastness of the world,\nl
Its distances were her nature's boundaries,\nl
Its closenesses her own life's intimacies.\nl
Her mind became familiar with its mind,\nl
Its body was her body's larger frame\nl
In which she lived and knew herself in it\nl
One, multitudinous in its multitudes.\nl
She was a single being, yet all things;\nl
The world was her spirit's wide circumference,\nl
The thoughts of others were her intimates,\nl
Their feelings close to her universal heart,\nl
Their bodies her many bodies kin to her;\nl
She was no more herself but all the world.\nl
Page 556

Out of the infinitudes all came to her,\nl
Into the infinitudes sentient she spread,\nl
Infinity was her own natural home.\nl
Nowhere she dwelt, her spirit was everywhere,\nl
The distant constellations wheeled round her;\nl
Earth saw her born, all worlds were her colonies,\nl
The greater worlds of life and mind were hers;\nl
All Nature reproduced her in its lines,\nl
Its movements were large copies of her own.\nl
She was the single self of all these selves,\nl
She was in them and they were all in her.\nl
This first was an immense identity\nl
In which her own identity was lost:\nl
What seemed herself was an image of the Whole.\nl
She was a subconscient life of tree and flower,\nl
The outbreak of the honied buds of spring;\nl
She burned in the passion and splendour of the rose,\nl
She was the red heart of the passion-flower,\nl
The dream-white of the lotus in its pool.\nl
Out of subconscient life she climbed to mind,\nl
She was thought and the passion of the world's heart,\nl
She was the godhead hid in the heart of man,\nl
She was the climbing of his soul to God.\nl
The cosmos flowered in her, she was its bed.\nl
She was Time and the dreams of God in Time;\nl
She was Space and the wideness of his days.\nl
From this she rose where Time and Space were not;\nl
The superconscient was her native air,\nl
Infinity was her movement's natural space;\nl
Eternity looked out from her on Time.\nl
\rl{\fsc End of Canto Seven}
\rl{\fsc End of Book Seven}
Page 557

\par

\sect1
\par
\ht BOOK EIGHT: The Book of Death
Page 559

\sect2
\par
\ht Canto Three: Death in the Forest
\note{The Book of Death was taken from Canto Three of an early version of {\it Savitri} which had only six cantos and an epilogue. It was slightly revised at a late stage and a number of new lines were added, but it was never fully worked into the final version of the poem. Its original designation, “Canto Three”, has been retained as a reminder of this.}\nl
\par
\sbigcap Now it was here in this great golden dawn.\nl
By her still sleeping husband lain she gazed\nl
Into her past as one about to die\nl
Looks back upon the sunlit fields of life\nl
Where he too ran and sported with the rest,\nl
Lifting his head above the huge dark stream\nl
Into whose depths he must for ever plunge.\nl
All she had been and done she lived again.\nl
The whole year in a swift and eddying race\nl
Of memories swept through her and fled away\nl
Into the irrecoverable past.\nl
Then silently she rose and, service done,\nl
Bowed down to the great goddess simply carved\nl
By Satyavan upon a forest stone.\nl
What prayer she breathed her soul and Durga knew.\nl
Perhaps she felt in the dim forest huge\nl
The infinite Mother watching over her child,\nl
Perhaps the shrouded Voice spoke some still word.\nl
At last she came to the pale mother queen.\nl
She spoke but with guarded lips and tranquil face\nl
Lest some stray word or some betraying look\nl
Should let pass into the mother's unknowing breast,\nl
Slaying all happiness and need to live,\nl
A dire foreknowledge of the grief to come.\nl
Only the needed utterance passage found:\nl
All else she pressed back into her anguished heart\nl
And forced upon her speech an outward peace.\nl
Page 561

“One year that I have lived with Satyavan\nl
Here on the emerald edge of the vast woods\nl
In the iron ring of the enormous peaks\nl
Under the blue rifts of the forest sky,\nl
I have not gone into the silences\nl
Of this great woodland that enringed my thoughts\nl
With mystery, nor in its green miracles\nl
Wandered, but this small clearing was my world.\nl
Now has a strong desire seized all my heart\nl
To go with Satyavan holding his hand\nl
Into the life that he has loved and touch\nl
Herbs he has trod and know the forest flowers\nl
And hear at ease the birds and the scurrying life\nl
That starts and ceases, rich far rustle of boughs\nl
And all the mystic whispering of the woods.\nl
Release me now and let my heart have rest.”\nl
She answered: “Do as thy wise mind desires,\nl
O calm child-sovereign with the eyes that rule.\nl
I hold thee for a strong goddess who has come\nl
Pitying our barren days; so dost thou serve\nl
Even as a slave might, yet art thou beyond\nl
All that thou doest, all our minds conceive,\nl
Like the strong sun that serves earth from above.”\nl
Then the doomed husband and the woman who knew\nl
Went with linked hands into that solemn world\nl
Where beauty and grandeur and unspoken dream,\nl
Where Nature's mystic silence could be felt\nl
Communing with the secrecy of God.\nl
Beside her Satyavan walked full of joy\nl
Because she moved with him through his green haunts:\nl
He showed her all the forest's riches, flowers\nl
Innumerable of every odour and hue\nl
And soft thick clinging creepers red and green\nl
And strange rich-plumaged birds, to every cry\nl
That haunted sweetly distant boughs replied\nl
With the shrill singer's name more sweetly called.\nl
Page 562

He spoke of all the things he loved: they were\nl
His boyhood's comrades and his playfellows,\nl
Coevals and companions of his life\nl
Here in this world whose every mood he knew:\nl
Their thoughts which to the common mind are blank,\nl
He shared, to every wild emotion felt\nl
An answer. Deeply she listened, but to hear\nl
The voice that soon would cease from tender words\nl
And treasure its sweet cadences beloved\nl
For lonely memory when none by her walked\nl
And the beloved voice could speak no more.\nl
But little dwelt her mind upon their sense;\nl
Of death, not life she thought or life's lone end.\nl
Love in her bosom hurt with the jagged edges\nl
Of anguish moaned at every step with pain\nl
Crying, “Now, now perhaps his voice will cease\nl
For ever.” Even by some vague touch oppressed\nl
Sometimes her eyes looked round as if their orbs\nl
Might see the dim and dreadful god's approach.\nl
But Satyavan had paused. He meant to finish\nl
His labour here that happy, linked, uncaring\nl
They two might wander free in the green deep\nl
Primaeval mystery of the forest's heart.\nl
A tree that raised its tranquil head to heaven\nl
Luxuriating in verdure, summoning\nl
The breeze with amorous wideness of its boughs,\nl
He chose and with his steel assailed the arm\nl
Brown, rough and strong hidden in its emerald dress.\nl
Wordless but near she watched, no turn to lose\nl
Of the bright face and body which she loved.\nl
Her life was now in seconds, not in hours,\nl
And every moment she economised\nl
Like a pale merchant leaned above his store,\nl
The miser of his poor remaining gold.\nl
But Satyavan wielded a joyous axe.\nl
He sang high snatches of a sage's chant\nl
Page 563

That pealed of conquered death and demons slain,\nl
And sometimes paused to cry to her sweet speech\nl
Of love and mockery tenderer than love:\nl
She like a pantheress leaped upon his words\nl
And carried them into her cavern heart.\nl
But as he worked, his doom upon him came.\nl
The violent and hungry hounds of pain\nl
Travelled through his body biting as they passed\nl
Silently, and all his suffering breath besieged\nl
Strove to rend life's strong heart-cords and be free.\nl
Then helped, as if a beast had left its prey,\nl
A moment in a wave of rich relief\nl
Reborn to strength and happy ease he stood\nl
Rejoicing and resumed his confident toil\nl
But with less seeing strokes. Now the great woodsman\nl
Hewed at him and his labour ceased: lifting\nl
His arm he flung away the poignant axe\nl
Far from him like an instrument of pain.\nl
She came to him in silent anguish and clasped,\nl
And he cried to her, “Savitri, a pang\nl
Cleaves through my head and breast as if the axe\nl
Were piercing it and not the living branch.\nl
Such agony rends me as the tree must feel\nl
When it is sundered and must lose its life.\nl
Awhile let me lay my head upon thy lap\nl
And guard me with thy hands from evil fate:\nl
Perhaps because thou touchest, death may pass.”\nl
Then Savitri sat under branches wide,\nl
Cool, green against the sun, not the hurt tree\nl
Which his keen axe had cloven,—that she shunned;\nl
But leaned beneath a fortunate kingly trunk\nl
She guarded him in her bosom and strove to soothe\nl
His anguished brow and body with her hands.\nl
All grief and fear were dead within her now\nl
And a great calm had fallen. The wish to lessen\nl
His suffering, the impulse that opposes pain\nl
Page 564

Were the one mortal feeling left. It passed:\nl
Griefless and strong she waited like the gods.\nl
But now his sweet familiar hue was changed\nl
Into a tarnished greyness and his eyes\nl
Dimmed over, forsaken of the clear light she loved.\nl
Only the dull and physical mind was left,\nl
Vacant of the bright spirit's luminous gaze.\nl
But once before it faded wholly back,\nl
He cried out in a clinging last despair,\nl
“Savitri, Savitri, O Savitri,\nl
Lean down, my soul, and kiss me while I die.”\nl
And even as her pallid lips pressed his,\nl
His failed, losing last sweetness of response;\nl
His cheek pressed down her golden arm. She sought\nl
His mouth still with her living mouth, as if\nl
She could persuade his soul back with her kiss;\nl
Then grew aware they were no more alone.\nl
Something had come there conscious, vast and dire.\nl
Near her she felt a silent shade immense\nl
Chilling the noon with darkness for its back.\nl
An awful hush had fallen upon the place:\nl
There was no cry of birds, no voice of beasts.\nl
A terror and an anguish filled the world,\nl
As if annihilation's mystery\nl
Had taken a sensible form. A cosmic mind\nl
Looked out on all from formidable eyes\nl
Contemning all with its unbearable gaze\nl
And with immortal lids and a vast brow\nl
It saw in its immense destroying thought\nl
All things and beings as a pitiful dream,\nl
Rejecting with calm disdain Nature's delight,\nl
The wordless meaning of its deep regard\nl
Voicing the unreality of things\nl
And life that would be for ever but never was\nl
And its brief and vain recurrence without cease,\nl
As if from a Silence without form or name\nl
Page 565

The Shadow of a remote uncaring god\nl
Doomed to his Nought the illusory universe,\nl
Cancelling its show of idea and act in Time\nl
And its imitation of eternity.\nl
She knew that visible Death was standing there\nl
And Satyavan had passed from her embrace.\nl
\rl{\fsc End of Book Eight}
\rl{\fsc End of Part Two}
Page 566

\sect1

\ht BOOK NINE: The Book of Eternal Night
Page 569

\sect2
\par
\ht Canto One: Towards the Black Void
\par
\sbigcap So was she left alone in the huge wood,\nl
Surrounded by a dim unthinking world,\nl
Her husband's corpse on her forsaken breast.\nl
In her vast silent spirit motionless\nl
She measured not her loss with helpless thoughts,\nl
Nor rent with tears the marble seals of pain:\nl
She rose not yet to face the dreadful god.\nl
Over the body she loved her soul leaned out\nl
In a great stillness without stir or voice,\nl
As if her mind had died with Satyavan.\nl
But still the human heart in her beat on.\nl
Aware still of his being near to hers,\nl
Closely she clasped to her the mute lifeless form\nl
As though to guard the oneness they had been\nl
And keep the spirit still within its frame.\nl
Then suddenly there came on her the change\nl
Which in tremendous moments of our lives\nl
Can overtake sometimes the human soul\nl
And hold it up towards its luminous source.\nl
The veil is torn, the thinker is no more:\nl
Only the spirit sees and all is known.\nl
Then a calm Power seated above our brows\nl
Is seen, unshaken by our thoughts and deeds,\nl
Its stillness bears the voices of the world:\nl
Immobile, it moves Nature, looks on life.\nl
It shapes immutably its far-seen ends;\nl
Untouched and tranquil amid error and tears\nl
And measureless above our striving wills,\nl
Its gaze controls the turbulent whirl of things.\nl
To mate with the Glory it sees, the spirit grows:\nl
The voice of life is tuned to infinite sounds,\nl
Page 571

The moments on great wings of lightning come\nl
And godlike thoughts surprise the mind of earth.\nl
Into the soul's splendour and intensity\nl
A crescent of miraculous birth is tossed,\nl
Whose horn of mystery floats in a bright void.\nl
As into a heaven of strength and silence thought\nl
Is ravished, all this living mortal clay\nl
Is seized and in a swift and fiery flood\nl
Of touches shaped by a Harmonist unseen.\nl
A new sight comes, new voices in us form\nl
A body of the music of the Gods.\nl
Immortal yearnings without name leap down,\nl
Large quiverings of godhead seeking run\nl
And weave upon a puissant field of calm\nl
A high and lonely ecstasy of will.\nl
This in a moment's depths was born in her.\nl
Now to the limitless gaze disclosed that sees\nl
Things barred from human thinking's earthly lids,\nl
The Spirit who had hidden in Nature soared\nl
Out of his luminous nest within the worlds:\nl
Like a vast fire it climbed the skies of night.\nl
Thus were the cords of self-oblivion torn:\nl
Like one who looks up to far heights she saw,\nl
Ancient and strong as on a windless summit\nl
Above her where she had worked in her lone mind\nl
Labouring apart in a sole tower of self,\nl
The source of all which she had seemed or wrought,\nl
A power projected into cosmic space,\nl
A slow embodiment of the aeonic will,\nl
A starry fragment of the eternal Truth,\nl
The passionate instrument of an unmoved Power.\nl
A Presence was there that filled the listening world;\nl
A central All assumed her boundless life.\nl
A sovereignty, a silence and a swiftness,\nl
One brooded over abysses who was she.\nl
As in a choric robe of unheard sounds\nl
Page 572

A Force descended trailing endless lights;\nl
Linking Time's seconds to infinity,\nl
Illimitably it girt the earth and her:\nl
It sank into her soul and she was changed.\nl
Then like a thought fulfilled by some great word\nl
That mightiness assumed a symbol form:\nl
Her being's spaces quivered with its touch,\nl
It covered her as with immortal wings;\nl
On its lips the curve of the unuttered Truth,\nl
A halo of Wisdom's lightnings for its crown,\nl
It entered the mystic lotus in her head,\nl
A thousand-petalled home of power and light.\nl
Immortal leader of her mortality,\nl
Doer of her works and fountain of her words,\nl
Invulnerable by Time, omnipotent,\nl
It stood above her calm, immobile, mute.\nl

\spar All in her mated with that mighty hour,\nl
As if the last remnant had been slain by Death\nl
Of the humanity that once was hers.\nl
Assuming a spiritual wide control,\nl
Making life's sea a mirror of heaven's sky,\nl
The young divinity in her earthly limbs\nl
Filled with celestial strength her mortal part.\nl
Over was the haunted pain, the rending fear:\nl
Her grief had passed away, her mind was still,\nl
Her heart beat quietly with a sovereign force.\nl
There came a freedom from the heart-strings' clutch,\nl
Now all her acts sprang from a godhead's calm.\nl
Calmly she laid upon the forest soil\nl
The dead who still reposed upon her breast\nl
And bore to turn away from the dead form:\nl
Sole now she rose to meet the dreadful god.\nl
That mightier spirit turned its mastering gaze\nl
On life and things, inheritor of a work\nl
Left to it unfinished from her halting past,\nl
Page 573

When yet the mind, a passionate learner, toiled\nl
And ill-shaped instruments were crudely moved.\nl
Transcended now was the poor human rule;\nl
A sovereign power was there, a godlike will.\nl
A moment yet she lingered motionless\nl
And looked down on the dead man at her feet;\nl
Then like a tree recovering from a wind\nl
She raised her noble head; fronting her gaze\nl
Something stood there, unearthly, sombre, grand,\nl
A limitless denial of all being\nl
That wore the terror and wonder of a shape.\nl
In its appalling eyes the tenebrous Form\nl
Bore the deep pity of destroying gods;\nl
A sorrowful irony curved the dreadful lips\nl
That speak the word of doom. Eternal Night\nl
In the dire beauty of an immortal face\nl
Pitying arose, receiving all that lives\nl
For ever into its fathomless heart, refuge\nl
Of creatures from their anguish and world-pain.\nl
His shape was nothingness made real, his limbs\nl
Were monuments of transience and beneath\nl
Brows of unwearying calm large godlike lids\nl
Silent beheld the writhing serpent, life.\nl
Unmoved their timeless wide unchanging gaze\nl
Had seen the unprofitable cycles pass,\nl
Survived the passing of unnumbered stars\nl
And sheltered still the same immutable orbs.\nl
The two opposed each other with their eyes,\nl
Woman and universal god: around her,\nl
Piling their void unbearable loneliness\nl
Upon her mighty uncompanioned soul,\nl
Many inhuman solitudes came close.\nl
Vacant eternities forbidding hope\nl
Laid upon her their huge and lifeless look,\nl
And to her ears, silencing earthly sounds,\nl
A sad and formidable voice arose\nl
Page 574

Which seemed the whole adverse world's. “Unclasp”, it cried,\nl
“Thy passionate influence and relax, O slave\nl
Of Nature, changing tool of changeless Law,\nl
Who vainly writh'st rebellion to my yoke,\nl
Thy elemental grasp; weep and forget.\nl
Entomb thy passion in its living grave.\nl
Leave now the once-loved spirit's abandoned robe:\nl
Pass lonely back to thy vain life on earth.”\nl
It ceased, she moved not, and it spoke again,\nl
Lowering its mighty key to human chords,—\nl
Yet a dread cry behind the uttered sounds,\nl
Echoing all sadness and immortal scorn,\nl
Moaned like a hunger of far wandering waves.\nl
“Wilt thou for ever keep thy passionate hold,\nl
Thyself a creature doomed like him to pass,\nl
Denying his soul death's calm and silent rest?\nl
Relax thy grasp; this body is earth's and thine,\nl
His spirit now belongs to a greater power.\nl
Woman, thy husband suffers.” Savitri\nl
Drew back her heart's force that clasped his body still\nl
Where from her lap renounced on the smooth grass\nl
Softly it lay, as often before in sleep\nl
When from their couch she rose in the white dawn\nl
Called by her daily tasks: now too, as if called,\nl
She rose and stood gathered in lonely strength,\nl
Like one who drops his mantle for a race\nl
And waits the signal, motionlessly swift.\nl
She knew not to what course: her spirit above\nl
On the crypt-summit of her secret form\nl
Like one left sentinel on a mountain crest,\nl
A fiery-footed splendour puissant-winged,\nl
Watched flaming-silent, with her voiceless soul\nl
Like a still sail upon a windless sea.\nl
White passionless it rode, an anchored might,\nl
Waiting what far-ridged impulse should arise\nl
Out of the eternal depths and cast its surge.\nl
Page 575

Then Death the king leaned boundless down, as leans\nl
Night over tired lands, when evening pales\nl
And fading gleams break down the horizon's walls,\nl
Nor yet the dusk grows mystic with the moon.\nl
The dim and awful godhead rose erect\nl
From his brief stooping to his touch on earth,\nl
And, like a dream that wakes out of a dream,\nl
Forsaking the poor mould of that dead clay,\nl
Another luminous Satyavan arose,\nl
Starting upright from the recumbent earth\nl
As if someone over viewless borders stepped\nl
Emerging on the edge of unseen worlds.\nl
In the earth's day the silent marvel stood\nl
Between the mortal woman and the god.\nl
Such seemed he as if one departed came\nl
Wearing the light of a celestial shape\nl
Splendidly alien to the mortal air.\nl
The mind sought things long loved and fell back foiled\nl
From unfamiliar hues, beheld yet longed,\nl
By the sweet radiant form unsatisfied,\nl
Incredulous of its too bright hints of heaven;\nl
Too strange the brilliant phantasm to life's clasp\nl
Desiring the warm creations of the earth\nl
Reared in the ardour of material suns,\nl
The senses seized in vain a glorious shade:\nl
Only the spirit knew the spirit still,\nl
And the heart divined the old loved heart, though changed.\nl
Between two realms he stood, not wavering,\nl
But fixed in quiet strong expectancy,\nl
Like one who, sightless, listens for a command.\nl
So were they immobile on that earthly field,\nl
Powers not of earth, though one in human clay.\nl
On either side of one two spirits strove;\nl
Silence battled with silence, vast with vast.\nl
But now the impulse of the Path was felt\nl
Moving from the Silence that supports the stars\nl
Page 576

To touch the confines of the visible world.\nl
Luminous he moved away; behind him Death\nl
Went slowly with his noiseless tread, as seen\nl
In dream-built fields a shadowy herdsman glides\nl
Behind some wanderer from his voiceless herds,\nl
And Savitri moved behind eternal Death,\nl
Her mortal pace was equalled with the god's.\nl
Wordless she travelled in her lover's steps,\nl
Planting her human feet where his had trod,\nl
Into the perilous silences beyond.\nl

\spar At first in a blind stress of woods she moved\nl
With strange inhuman paces on the soil,\nl
Journeying as if upon an unseen road.\nl
Around her on the green and imaged earth\nl
The flickering screen of forests ringed her steps;\nl
Its thick luxurious obstacle of boughs\nl
Besieged her body pressing dimly through\nl
In a rich realm of whispers palpable,\nl
And all the murmurous beauty of the leaves\nl
Rippled around her like an emerald robe.\nl
But more and more this grew an alien sound,\nl
And her old intimate body seemed to her\nl
A burden which her being remotely bore.\nl
Herself lived far in some uplifted scene\nl
Where to the trance-claimed vision of pursuit,\nl
Sole presences in a high spaceless dream,\nl
The luminous spirit glided stilly on\nl
And the great shadow travelled vague behind.\nl
Still with an amorous crowd of seeking hands\nl
Softly entreated by their old desires\nl
Her senses felt earth's close and gentle air\nl
Cling round them and in troubled branches knew\nl
Uncertain treadings of a faint-foot wind:\nl
She bore dim fragrances, far callings touched;\nl
The wild bird's voice and its winged rustle came\nl
Page 577

As if a sigh from some forgotten world.\nl
Earth stood aloof, yet near: round her it wove\nl
Its sweetness and its greenness and delight,\nl
Its brilliance suave of well-loved vivid hues,\nl
Sunlight arriving to its golden noon,\nl
And the blue heavens and the caressing soil.\nl
The ancient mother offered to her child\nl
Her simple world of kind familiar things.\nl
But now, as if the body's sensuous hold\nl
Curbing the godhead of her infinite walk\nl
Had freed those spirits to their grander road\nl
Across some boundary's intangible bar,\nl
The silent god grew mighty and remote\nl
In other spaces, and the soul she loved\nl
Lost its consenting nearness to her life.\nl
Into a deep and unfamiliar air\nl
Enormous, windless, without stir or sound\nl
They seemed to enlarge away, drawn by some wide\nl
Pale distance, from the warm control of earth\nl
And her grown far: now, now they would escape.\nl
Then flaming from her body's nest alarmed\nl
Her violent spirit soared at Satyavan.\nl
Out mid the plunge of heaven-surrounded rocks\nl
So in a terror and a wrath divine\nl
From her eyrie streams against the ascending death,\nl
Indignant at its crouching point of steel,\nl
A fierce she-eagle threatened in her brood,\nl
Borne on a rush of puissance and a cry,\nl
Outwinging like a mass of golden fire.\nl
So on a spirit's flaming outrush borne\nl
She crossed the borders of dividing sense;\nl
Like pale discarded sheaths dropped dully down\nl
Her mortal members fell back from her soul.\nl
A moment of a secret body's sleep,\nl
Her trance knew not of sun or earth or world;\nl
Thought, time and death were absent from her grasp:\nl
Page 578

She knew not self, forgotten was Savitri.\nl
All was the violent ocean of a will\nl
Where lived captive to an immense caress,\nl
Possessed in a supreme identity,\nl
Her aim, joy, origin, Satyavan alone.\nl
Her sovereign prisoned in her being's core,\nl
He beat there like a rhythmic heart,—herself\nl
But different still, one loved, enveloped, clasped,\nl
A treasure saved from the collapse of space.\nl
Around him nameless, infinite she surged,\nl
Her spirit fulfilled in his spirit, rich with all Time,\nl
As if Love's deathless moment had been found,\nl
A pearl within eternity's white shell.\nl
Then out of the engulfing sea of trance\nl
Her mind rose drenched to light streaming with hues\nl
Of vision and, awake once more to Time,\nl
Returned to shape the lineaments of things\nl
And live in borders of the seen and known.\nl
Onward the three still moved in her soul-scene.\nl
As if pacing through fragments of a dream,\nl
She seemed to travel on, a visioned shape\nl
Imagining other musers like herself,\nl
By them imagined in their lonely sleep.\nl
Ungrasped, unreal, yet familiar, old,\nl
Like clefts of unsubstantial memory,\nl
Scenes often traversed, never lived in, fled\nl
Past her unheeding to forgotten goals.\nl
In voiceless regions they were travellers\nl
Alone in a new world where souls were not,\nl
But only living moods: a strange hushed weird\nl
Country was round them, strange far skies above,\nl
A doubting space where dreaming objects lived\nl
Within themselves their one unchanged idea.\nl
Weird were the grasses, weird the treeless plains;\nl
Weird ran the road which like fear hastening\nl
Towards that of which it has most terror, passed\nl
Page 579

Phantasmal between pillared conscious rocks\nl
Sombre and high, gates brooding, whose stone thoughts\nl
Lost their huge sense beyond in giant night.\nl
Enigma of the Inconscient's sculptural sleep,\nl
Symbols of the approach to darkness old\nl
And monuments of her titanic reign,\nl
Opening to depths like dumb appalling jaws\nl
That wait a traveller down a haunted path\nl
Attracted to a mystery that slays,\nl
They watched across her road, cruel and still;\nl
Sentinels they stood of dumb Necessity,\nl
Mute heads of vigilant and sullen gloom,\nl
Carved muzzle of a dim enormous world.\nl
Then, to that chill sere heavy line arrived\nl
Where his feet touched the shadowy marches' brink,\nl
Turning arrested luminous Satyavan\nl
Looked back with his wonderful eyes at Savitri.\nl
But Death pealed forth his vast abysmal cry:\nl
“O mortal, turn back to thy transient kind;\nl
Aspire not to accompany Death to his home,\nl
As if thy breath could live where Time must die.\nl
Think not thy mind-born passion strength from heaven\nl
To uplift thy spirit from its earthly base\nl
And, breaking out from the material cage,\nl
To upbuoy thy feet of dream in groundless Nought\nl
And bear thee through the pathless infinite.\nl
Only in human limits man lives safe.\nl
Trust not in the unreal Lords of Time,\nl
Immortal deeming this image of thyself\nl
Which they have built on a Dream's floating ground.\nl
Let not the dreadful goddess move thy soul\nl
To enlarge thy vehement trespass into worlds\nl
Where it shall perish like a helpless thought.\nl
Know the cold term-stones of thy hopes in life.\nl
Armed vainly with the Ideal's borrowed might,\nl
Dare not to outstep man's bound and measured force:\nl
Page 580

Ignorant and stumbling, in brief boundaries pent,\nl
He crowns himself the world's mock suzerain,\nl
Tormenting Nature with the works of Mind.\nl
O sleeper, dreaming of divinity,\nl
Wake trembling mid the indifferent silences\nl
In which thy few weak chords of being die.\nl
Impermanent creatures, sorrowful foam of Time,\nl
Your transient loves bind not the eternal gods.”\nl
The dread voice ebbed in the consenting hush\nl
Which seemed to close upon it, wide, intense,\nl
A wordless sanction from the jaws of Night.\nl
The Woman answered not. Her high nude soul,\nl
Stripped of the girdle of mortality,\nl
Against fixed destiny and the grooves of law\nl
Stood up in its sheer will a primal force.\nl
Still like a statue on its pedestal,\nl
Lone in the silence and to vastness bared,\nl
Against midnight's dumb abysses piled in front\nl
A columned shaft of fire and light she rose.\nl
\rl{\fsc End of Canto One}
Page 581

\par
\ht Canto Two: The Journey in Eternal Night and the Voice of the Darkness
\par
\sbigcap Awhile on the chill dreadful edge of Night\nl
All stood as if a world were doomed to die\nl
And waited on the eternal silence' brink.\nl
Heaven leaned towards them like a cloudy brow\nl
Of menace through the dim and voiceless hush.\nl
As thoughts stand mute on a despairing verge\nl
Where the last depths plunge into nothingness\nl
And the last dreams must end, they paused; in their front\nl
Were glooms like shadowy wings, behind them, pale,\nl
The lifeless evening was a dead man's gaze.\nl
Hungry beyond, the night desired her soul.\nl
But still in its lone niche of templed strength\nl
Motionless, her flame-bright spirit, mute, erect,\nl
Burned like a torch-fire from a windowed room\nl
Pointing against the darkness' sombre breast.\nl
The Woman first affronted the Abyss\nl
Daring to journey through the eternal Night.\nl
Armoured with light she advanced her foot to plunge\nl
Into the dread and hueless vacancy;\nl
Immortal, unappalled, her spirit faced\nl
The danger of the ruthless eyeless waste.\nl
Against night's inky ground they stirred, moulding\nl
Mysterious motion on her human tread,\nl
A swimming action and a drifting march\nl
Like figures moving before eyelids closed:\nl
All as in dreams went slipping, gliding on.\nl
The rock-gate's heavy walls were left behind;\nl
As if through passages of receding time\nl
Present and past into the Timeless lapsed;\nl
Arrested upon dim adventure's brink,\nl
Page 582

The future ended drowned in nothingness.\nl
Amid collapsing shapes they wound obscure;\nl
The fading vestibules of a tenebrous world\nl
Received them, where they seemed to move and yet\nl
Be still, nowhere advancing yet to pass,\nl
A dumb procession a dim picture bounds,\nl
Not conscious forms threading a real scene.\nl
A mystery of terror's boundlessness,\nl
Gathering its hungry strength the huge pitiless void\nl
Surrounded slowly with its soundless depths,\nl
And monstrous, cavernous, a shapeless throat\nl
Devoured her into its shadowy strangling mass,\nl
The fierce spiritual agony of a dream.\nl
A curtain of impenetrable dread,\nl
The darkness hung around her cage of sense\nl
As, when the trees have turned to blotted shades\nl
And the last friendly glimmer fades away,\nl
Around a bullock in the forest tied\nl
By hunters closes in no empty night.\nl
The thought that strives in the world was here unmade;\nl
Its effort it renounced to live and know,\nl
Convinced at last that it had never been;\nl
It perished, all its dream of action done:\nl
This clotted cypher was its dark result.\nl
In the smothering stress of this stupendous Nought\nl
Mind could not think, breath could not breathe, the soul\nl
Could not remember or feel itself; it seemed\nl
A hollow gulf of sterile emptiness,\nl
A zero oblivious of the sum it closed,\nl
An abnegation of the Maker's joy\nl
Saved by no wide repose, no depth of peace.\nl
On all that claims here to be Truth and God\nl
And conscious self and the revealing Word\nl
And the creative rapture of the Mind\nl
And Love and Knowledge and heart's delight, there fell\nl
The immense refusal of the eternal No.\nl
Page 583

As disappears a golden lamp in gloom\nl
Borne into distance from the eyes' desire,\nl
Into the shadows vanished Savitri.\nl
There was no course, no path, no end or goal:\nl
Visionless she moved amid insensible gulfs,\nl
Or drove through some great black unknowing waste,\nl
Or whirled in a dumb eddy of meeting winds\nl
Assembled by the titan hands of Chance.\nl
There was none with her in the dreadful Vast:\nl
She saw no more the vague tremendous god,\nl
Her eyes had lost their luminous Satyavan.\nl
Yet not for this her spirit failed, but held\nl
More deeply than the bounded senses can\nl
Which grasp externally and find to lose,\nl
Its object loved. So when on earth they lived\nl
She had felt him straying through the glades, the glades\nl
A scene in her, its clefts her being's vistas\nl
Opening their secrets to his search and joy,\nl
Because to jealous sweetness in her heart\nl
Whatever happy space his cherished feet\nl
Preferred, must be at once her soul embracing\nl
His body, passioning dumbly to his tread.\nl
But now a silent gulf between them came\nl
And to abysmal loneliness she fell,\nl
Even from herself cast out, from love remote.\nl
Long hours, since long it seems when sluggish time\nl
Is measured by the throbs of the soul's pain,\nl
In an unreal darkness empty and drear\nl
She travelled treading on the corpse of life,\nl
Lost in a blindness of extinguished souls.\nl
Solitary in the anguish of the void\nl
She lived in spite of death, she conquered still;\nl
In vain her puissant being was oppressed:\nl
Her heavy long monotony of pain\nl
Tardily of its fierce self-torture tired.\nl
At first a faint inextinguishable gleam,\nl
Page 584

Pale but immortal, flickered in the gloom\nl
As if a memory came to spirits dead,\nl
A memory that wished to live again,\nl
Dissolved from mind in Nature's natal sleep.\nl
It wandered like a lost ray of the moon\nl
Revealing to the night her soul of dread;\nl
Serpentine in the gleam the darkness lolled,\nl
Its black hoods jewelled with the mystic glow;\nl
Its dull sleek folds shrank back and coiled and slid,\nl
As though they felt all light a cruel pain\nl
And suffered from the pale approach of hope.\nl
Night felt assailed her heavy sombre reign;\nl
The splendour of some bright eternity\nl
Threatened with this faint beam of wandering Truth\nl
Her empire of the everlasting Nought.\nl
Implacable in her intolerant strength\nl
And confident that she alone was true,\nl
She strove to stifle the frail dangerous ray;\nl
Aware of an all-negating immensity\nl
She reared her giant head of Nothingness,\nl
Her mouth of darkness swallowing all that is;\nl
She saw in herself the tenebrous Absolute.\nl
But still the light prevailed and still it grew,\nl
And Savitri to her lost self awoke;\nl
Her limbs refused the cold embrace of death,\nl
Her heart-beats triumphed in the grasp of pain;\nl
Her soul persisted claiming for its joy\nl
The soul of the beloved now seen no more.\nl
Before her in the stillness of the world\nl
Once more she heard the treading of a god,\nl
And out of the dumb darkness Satyavan,\nl
Her husband, grew into a luminous shade.\nl
Then a sound pealed through that dead monstrous realm:\nl
Vast like the surge in a tired swimmer's ears,\nl
Clamouring, a fatal iron-hearted roar,\nl
Death missioned to the night his lethal call.\nl
Page 585

“This is my silent dark immensity,\nl
This is the home of everlasting Night,\nl
This is the secrecy of Nothingness\nl
Entombing the vanity of life's desires.\nl
Hast thou beheld thy source, O transient heart,\nl
And known from what the dream thou art was made?\nl
In this stark sincerity of nude emptiness\nl
Hopest thou still always to last and love?”\nl
The Woman answered not. Her spirit refused\nl
The voice of Night that knew and Death that thought.\nl
In her beginningless infinity\nl
Through her soul's reaches unconfined she gazed;\nl
She saw the undying fountains of her life,\nl
She knew herself eternal without birth.\nl
But still opposing her with endless night\nl
Death, the dire god, inflicted on her eyes\nl
The immortal calm of his tremendous gaze:\nl
“Although thou hast survived the unborn void\nl
Which never shall forgive, while Time endures,\nl
The primal violence that fashioned thought,\nl
Forcing the immobile vast to suffer and live,\nl
This sorrowful victory only hast thou won\nl
To live for a little without Satyavan.\nl
What shall the ancient goddess give to thee\nl
Who helps thy heart-beats? Only she prolongs\nl
The nothing dreamed existence and delays\nl
With the labour of living thy eternal sleep.\nl
A fragile miracle of thinking clay,\nl
Armed with illusions walks the child of Time.\nl
To fill the void around he feels and dreads,\nl
The void he came from and to which he goes,\nl
He magnifies his self and names it God.\nl
He calls the heavens to help his suffering hopes.\nl
He sees above him with a longing heart\nl
Bare spaces more unconscious than himself\nl
That have not even his privilege of mind,\nl
Page 586

And empty of all but their unreal blue,\nl
And peoples them with bright and merciful powers.\nl
For the sea roars around him and earth quakes\nl
Beneath his steps, and fire is at his doors,\nl
And death prowls baying through the woods of life.\nl
Moved by the Presences with which he yearns,\nl
He offers in implacable shrines his soul\nl
And clothes all with the beauty of his dreams.\nl
The gods who watch the earth with sleepless eyes\nl
And guide its giant stumblings through the void,\nl
Have given to man the burden of his mind;\nl
In his unwilling heart they have lit their fires\nl
And sown in it incurable unrest.\nl
His mind is a hunter upon tracks unknown;\nl
Amusing Time with vain discovery,\nl
He deepens with thought the mystery of his fate\nl
And turns to song his laughter and his tears.\nl
His mortality vexing with the immortal's dreams,\nl
Troubling his transience with the infinite's breath,\nl
They gave him hungers which no food can fill;\nl
He is the cattle of the shepherd gods.\nl
His body the tether with which he is tied,\nl
They cast for fodder grief and hope and joy:\nl
His pasture ground they have fenced with Ignorance.\nl
Into his fragile undefended breast\nl
They have breathed a courage that is met by death,\nl
They have given a wisdom that is mocked by night,\nl
They have traced a journey that foresees no goal.\nl
Aimless man toils in an uncertain world,\nl
Lulled by inconstant pauses of his pain,\nl
Scourged like a beast by the infinite desire,\nl
Bound to the chariot of the dreadful gods.\nl
But if thou still canst hope and still wouldst love,\nl
Return to thy body's shell, thy tie to earth,\nl
And with thy heart's little remnants try to live.\nl
Hope not to win back to thee Satyavan.\nl
Page 587

Yet since thy strength deserves no trivial crown,\nl
Gifts I can give to soothe thy wounded life.\nl
The pacts which transient beings make with fate,\nl
And the wayside sweetness earth-bound hearts would pluck,\nl
These if thy will accepts make freely thine.\nl
Choose a life's hopes for thy deceiving prize.”\nl
As ceased the ruthless and tremendous Voice,\nl
Unendingly there rose in Savitri,\nl
Like moonlit ridges on a shuddering flood,\nl
A stir of thoughts out of some silence born\nl
Across the sea of her dumb fathomless heart.\nl
At last she spoke; her voice was heard by Night:\nl
“I bow not to thee, O huge mask of death,\nl
Black lie of night to the cowed soul of man,\nl
Unreal, inescapable end of things,\nl
Thou grim jest played with the immortal spirit.\nl
Conscious of immortality I walk.\nl
A victor spirit conscious of my force,\nl
Not as a suppliant to thy gates I came:\nl
Unslain I have survived the clutch of Night.\nl
My first strong grief moves not my seated mind;\nl
My unwept tears have turned to pearls of strength:\nl
I have transformed my ill-shaped brittle clay\nl
Into the hardness of a statued soul.\nl
Now in the wrestling of the splendid gods\nl
My spirit shall be obstinate and strong\nl
Against the vast refusal of the world.\nl
I stoop not with the subject mob of minds\nl
Who run to glean with eager satisfied hands\nl
And pick from its mire mid many trampling feet\nl
Its scornful small concessions to the weak.\nl
Mine is the labour of the battling gods:\nl
Imposing on the slow reluctant years\nl
The flaming will that reigns beyond the stars,\nl
They lay the law of Mind on Matter's works\nl
And win the soul's wish from earth's inconscient Force.\nl
Page 588

First I demand whatever Satyavan,\nl
My husband, waking in the forest's charm\nl
Out of his long pure childhood's lonely dreams,\nl
Desired and had not for his beautiful life.\nl
Give, if thou must, or, if thou canst, refuse.”\nl
Death bowed his head in scornful cold assent,\nl
The builder of this dreamlike earth for man\nl
Who has mocked with vanity all gifts he gave.\nl
Uplifting his disastrous voice he spoke:\nl
“Indulgent to the dreams my touch shall break,\nl
I yield to his blind father's longing heart\nl
Kingdom and power and friends and greatness lost\nl
And royal trappings for his peaceful age,\nl
The pallid pomps of man's declining days,\nl
The silvered decadent glories of life's fall.\nl
To one who wiser grew by adverse Fate,\nl
Goods I restore the deluded soul prefers\nl
To impersonal nothingness's bare sublime.\nl
The sensuous solace of the light I give\nl
To eyes which could have found a larger realm,\nl
A deeper vision in their fathomless night.\nl
For that this man desired and asked in vain\nl
While still he lived on earth and cherished hope.\nl
Back from the grandeur of my perilous realms\nl
Go, mortal, to thy small permitted sphere!\nl
Hasten swift-footed, lest to slay thy life\nl
The great laws thou hast violated, moved,\nl
Open at last on thee their marble eyes.”\nl
But Savitri answered the disdainful Shade:\nl
“World-spirit, I was thy equal spirit born.\nl
My will too is a law, my strength a god.\nl
I am immortal in my mortality.\nl
I tremble not before the immobile gaze\nl
Of the unchanging marble hierarchies\nl
That look with the stone eyes of Law and Fate.\nl
My soul can meet them with its living fire.\nl
Page 589

Out of thy shadow give me back again\nl
Into earth's flowering spaces Satyavan\nl
In the sweet transiency of human limbs\nl
To do with him my spirit's burning will.\nl
I will bear with him the ancient Mother's load,\nl
I will follow with him earth's path that leads to God.\nl
Else shall the eternal spaces open to me,\nl
While round us strange horizons far recede,\nl
Travelling together the immense unknown.\nl
For I who have trod with him the tracts of Time,\nl
Can meet behind his steps whatever night\nl
Or unimaginable stupendous dawn\nl
Breaks on our spirits in the untrod Beyond.\nl
Wherever thou leadst his soul I shall pursue.”\nl
But to her claim opposed, implacable,\nl
Insisting on the immutable Decree,\nl
Insisting on the immitigable Law\nl
And the insignificance of created things,\nl
Out of the rolling wastes of night there came\nl
Born from the enigma of the unknowable depths\nl
A voice of majesty and appalling scorn.\nl
As when the storm-haired Titan-striding sea\nl
Throws on a swimmer its tremendous laugh\nl
Remembering all the joy its waves have drowned,\nl
So from the darkness of the sovereign night\nl
Against the Woman's boundless heart arose\nl
The almighty cry of universal Death.\nl
“Hast thou god-wings or feet that tread my stars,\nl
Frail creature with the courage that aspires,\nl
Forgetting thy bounds of thought, thy mortal role?\nl
Their orbs were coiled before thy soul was formed.\nl
I, Death, created them out of my void;\nl
All things I have built in them and I destroy.\nl
I made the worlds my net, each joy a mesh.\nl
A Hunger amorous of its suffering prey,\nl
Life that devours, my image see in things.\nl
Page 590

Mortal, whose spirit is my wandering breath,\nl
Whose transience was imagined by my smile,\nl
Flee clutching thy poor gains to thy trembling breast\nl
Pierced by my pangs Time shall not soon appease.\nl
Blind slave of my deaf force whom I compel\nl
To sin that I may punish, to desire\nl
That I may scourge thee with despair and grief\nl
And thou come bleeding to me at the last,\nl
Thy nothingness recognised, my greatness known,\nl
Turn nor attempt forbidden happy fields\nl
Meant for the souls that can obey my law,\nl
Lest in their sombre shrines thy tread awake\nl
From their uneasy iron-hearted sleep\nl
The Furies who avenge fulfilled desire.\nl
Dread lest in skies where passion hoped to live,\nl
The Unknown's lightnings start and, terrified,\nl
Lone, sobbing, hunted by the hounds of heaven,\nl
A wounded and forsaken soul thou flee\nl
Through the long torture of the centuries,\nl
Nor many lives exhaust the tireless Wrath\nl
Hell cannot slake nor Heaven's mercy assuage.\nl
I will take from thee the black eternal grip:\nl
Clasping in thy heart thy fate's exiguous dole\nl
Depart in peace, if peace for man is just.”\nl
But Savitri answered meeting scorn with scorn,\nl
The mortal woman to the dreadful Lord:\nl
“Who is this God imagined by thy night,\nl
Contemptuously creating worlds disdained,\nl
Who made for vanity the brilliant stars?\nl
Not he who has reared his temple in my thoughts\nl
And made his sacred floor my human heart.\nl
My God is will and triumphs in his paths,\nl
My God is love and sweetly suffers all.\nl
To him I have offered hope for sacrifice\nl
And gave my longings as a sacrament.\nl
Who shall prohibit or hedge in his course,\nl
Page 591

The wonderful, the charioteer, the swift?\nl
A traveller of the million roads of life,\nl
His steps familiar with the lights of heaven\nl
Tread without pain the sword-paved courts of hell;\nl
There he descends to edge eternal joy.\nl
Love's golden wings have power to fan thy void:\nl
The eyes of love gaze starlike through death's night,\nl
The feet of love tread naked hardest worlds.\nl
He labours in the depths, exults on the heights;\nl
He shall remake thy universe, O Death.”\nl
She spoke and for a while no voice replied,\nl
While still they travelled through the trackless night\nl
And still that gleam was like a pallid eye\nl
Troubling the darkness with its doubtful gaze.\nl
Then once more came a deep and perilous pause\nl
In that unreal journey through blind Nought;\nl
Once more a Thought, a Word in the void arose\nl
And Death made answer to the human soul:\nl
“What is thy hope? to what dost thou aspire?\nl
This is thy body's sweetest lure of bliss,\nl
Assailed by pain, a frail precarious form,\nl
To please for a few years thy faltering sense\nl
With honey of physical longings and the heart's fire\nl
And, a vain oneness seeking, to embrace\nl
The brilliant idol of a fugitive hour.\nl
And thou, what art thou, soul, thou glorious dream\nl
Of brief emotions made and glittering thoughts,\nl
A thin dance of fireflies speeding through the night,\nl
A sparkling ferment in life's sunlit mire?\nl
Wilt thou claim immortality, O heart,\nl
Crying against the eternal witnesses\nl
That thou and he are endless powers and last?\nl
Death only lasts and the inconscient Void.\nl
I only am eternal and endure.\nl
I am the shapeless formidable Vast,\nl
I am the emptiness that men call Space,\nl
Page 592

I am a timeless Nothingness carrying all,\nl
I am the Illimitable, the mute Alone.\nl
I, Death, am He; there is no other God.\nl
All from my depths are born, they live by death;\nl
All to my depths return and are no more.\nl
I have made a world by my inconscient Force.\nl
My Force is Nature that creates and slays\nl
The hearts that hope, the limbs that long to live.\nl
I have made man her instrument and slave,\nl
His body I made my banquet, his life my food.\nl
Man has no other help but only Death;\nl
He comes to me at his end for rest and peace.\nl
I, Death, am the one refuge of thy soul.\nl
The Gods to whom man prays can help not man;\nl
They are my imaginations and my moods\nl
Reflected in him by illusion's power.\nl
That which thou seest as thy immortal self\nl
Is a shadowy icon of my infinite,\nl
Is Death in thee dreaming of eternity.\nl
I am the Immobile in which all things move,\nl
I am the nude Inane in which they cease:\nl
I have no body and no tongue to speak,\nl
I commune not with human eye and ear;\nl
Only thy thought gave a figure to my void.\nl
Because, O aspirant to divinity,\nl
Thou calledst me to wrestle with thy soul,\nl
I have assumed a face, a form, a voice.\nl
But if there were a Being witnessing all,\nl
How should he help thy passionate desire?\nl
Aloof he watches sole and absolute,\nl
Indifferent to thy cry in nameless calm.\nl
His being is pure, unwounded, motionless, one.\nl
One endless watches the inconscient scene\nl
Where all things perish, as the foam the stars.\nl
The One lives for ever. There no Satyavan\nl
Changing was born and there no Savitri\nl
Page 593

Claims from brief life her bribe of joy. There love\nl
Came never with his fretful eyes of tears,\nl
Nor Time is there nor the vain vasts of Space.\nl
It wears no living face, it has no name,\nl
No gaze, no heart that throbs; it asks no second\nl
To aid its being or to share its joys.\nl
It is delight immortally alone.\nl
If thou desirest immortality,\nl
Be then alone sufficient to thy soul:\nl
Live in thyself; forget the man thou lov'st.\nl
My last grand death shall rescue thee from life;\nl
Then shalt thou rise into thy unmoved source.”\nl
But Savitri replied to the dread Voice:\nl
“O Death, who reasonest, I reason not,\nl
Reason that scans and breaks, but cannot build\nl
Or builds in vain because she doubts her work.\nl
I am, I love, I see, I act, I will.”\nl
Death answered her, one deep surrounding cry:\nl
“Know also. Knowing, thou shalt cease to love\nl
And cease to will, delivered from thy heart.\nl
So shalt thou rest for ever and be still,\nl
Consenting to the impermanence of things.”\nl
But Savitri replied for man to Death:\nl
“When I have loved for ever, I shall know.\nl
Love in me knows the truth all changings mask.\nl
I know that knowledge is a vast embrace:\nl
I know that every being is myself,\nl
In every heart is hidden the myriad One.\nl
I know the calm Transcendent bears the world,\nl
The veiled Inhabitant, the silent Lord:\nl
I feel his secret act, his intimate fire;\nl
I hear the murmur of the cosmic Voice.\nl
I know my coming was a wave from God.\nl
For all his suns were conscient in my birth,\nl
And one who loves in us came veiled by death.\nl
Then was man born among the monstrous stars\nl
Page 594

Dowered with a mind and heart to conquer thee.”\nl
In the eternity of his ruthless will\nl
Sure of his empire and his armoured might,\nl
Like one disdaining violent helpless words\nl
From victim lips Death answered not again.\nl
He stood in silence and in darkness wrapped,\nl
A figure motionless, a shadow vague,\nl
Girt with the terrors of his secret sword.\nl
Half-seen in clouds appeared a sombre face;\nl
Night's dusk tiara was his matted hair,\nl
The ashes of the pyre his forehead's sign.\nl
Once more a wanderer in the unending Night,\nl
Blindly forbidden by dead vacant eyes,\nl
She travelled through the dumb unhoping vasts.\nl
Around her rolled the shuddering waste of gloom,\nl
Its swallowing emptiness and joyless death\nl
Resentful of her thought and life and love.\nl
Through the long fading night by her compelled,\nl
Gliding half-seen on their unearthly path,\nl
Phantasmal in the dimness moved the three.\nl
\rl{\fsc End of Canto Two}
\rl{\fsc End of Book Nine}
Page 595

\sect1
\par
\ht BOOK TEN: The Book of the Double Twilight
Page 597

\sect2
\par
\ht Canto One: The Dream Twilight of the Ideal
\par
\sbigcap All still was darkness dread and desolate;\nl
There was no change nor any hope of change.\nl
In this black dream which was a house of Void,\nl
A walk to Nowhere in a land of Nought,\nl
Ever they drifted without aim or goal;\nl
Gloom led to worse gloom, depth to an emptier depth,\nl
In some positive Non-being's purposeless Vast\nl
Through formless wastes dumb and unknowable.\nl
An ineffectual beam of suffering light\nl
Through the despairing darkness dogged their steps\nl
Like the remembrance of a glory lost;\nl
Even while it grew, it seemed unreal there,\nl
Yet haunted Nihil's chill stupendous realm,\nl
Unquenchable, perpetual, lonely, null,\nl
A pallid ghost of some dead eternity.\nl
It was as if she must pay now her debt,\nl
Her vain presumption to exist and think,\nl
To some brilliant Maya that conceived her soul.\nl
This most she must absolve with endless pangs,\nl
Her deep original sin, the will to be\nl
And the sin last, greatest, the spiritual pride,\nl
That, made of dust, equalled itself with heaven,\nl
Its scorn of the worm writhing in the mud,\nl
Condemned ephemeral, born from Nature's dream,\nl
Refusal of the transient creature's role,\nl
The claim to be a living fire of God,\nl
The will to be immortal and divine.\nl
In that tremendous darkness heavy and bare\nl
She atoned for all since the first act whence sprang\nl
The error of the consciousness of Time,\nl
The rending of the Inconscient's seal of sleep,\nl
Page 599

The primal and unpardoned revolt that broke\nl
The peace and silence of the Nothingness\nl
Which was before a seeming universe\nl
Appeared in a vanity of imagined Space\nl
And life arose engendering grief and pain:\nl
A great Negation was the Real's face\nl
Prohibiting the vain process of Time:\nl
And when there is no world, no creature more,\nl
When Time's intrusion has been blotted out,\nl
It shall last, unbodied, saved from thought, at peace.\nl
Accursed in what had been her godhead source,\nl
Condemned to live for ever empty of bliss,\nl
Her immortality her chastisement,\nl
Her spirit, guilty of being, wandered doomed,\nl
Moving for ever through eternal Night.\nl
But Maya is a veil of the Absolute;\nl
A Truth occult has made this mighty world:\nl
The Eternal's wisdom and self-knowledge act\nl
In ignorant Mind and in the body's steps.\nl
The Inconscient is the Superconscient's sleep.\nl
An unintelligible Intelligence\nl
Invents creation's paradox profound;\nl
Spiritual thought is crammed in Matter's forms,\nl
Unseen it throws out a dumb energy\nl
And works a miracle by a machine.\nl
All here is a mystery of contraries:\nl
Darkness a magic of self-hidden Light,\nl
Suffering some secret rapture's tragic mask\nl
And death an instrument of perpetual life.\nl
Although Death walks beside us on Life's road,\nl
A dim bystander at the body's start\nl
And a last judgment on man's futile works,\nl
Other is the riddle of its ambiguous face:\nl
Death is a stair, a door, a stumbling stride\nl
The soul must take to cross from birth to birth,\nl
A grey defeat pregnant with victory,\nl
Page 600

A whip to lash us towards our deathless state.\nl
The inconscient world is the spirit's self-made room,\nl
Eternal Night shadow of eternal Day.\nl
Night is not our beginning nor our end;\nl
She is the dark Mother in whose womb we have hid\nl
Safe from too swift a waking to world-pain.\nl
We came to her from a supernal Light,\nl
By Light we live and to the Light we go.\nl
Here in this seat of Darkness mute and lone,\nl
In the heart of everlasting Nothingness\nl
Light conquered now even by that feeble beam:\nl
Its faint infiltration drilled the blind deaf mass;\nl
Almost it changed into a glimmering sight\nl
That housed the phantom of an aureate Sun\nl
Whose orb pupilled the eye of Nothingness.\nl
A golden fire came in and burned Night's heart;\nl
Her dusky mindlessness began to dream;\nl
The Inconscient conscious grew, Night felt and thought.\nl
Assailed in the sovereign emptiness of its reign\nl
The intolerant Darkness paled and drew apart\nl
Till only a few black remnants stained that Ray.\nl
But on a failing edge of dumb lost space\nl
Still a great dragon body sullenly loomed;\nl
Adversary of the slow struggling Dawn\nl
Defending its ground of tortured mystery,\nl
It trailed its coils through the dead martyred air\nl
And curving fled down a grey slope of Time.\nl

\spar There is a morning twilight of the gods;\nl
Miraculous from sleep their forms arise\nl
And God's long nights are justified by dawn.\nl
There breaks a passion and splendour of new birth\nl
And hue-winged visions stray across the lids,\nl
Heaven's chanting heralds waken dim-eyed Space.\nl
The dreaming deities look beyond the seen\nl
And fashion in their thoughts the ideal worlds\nl
Page 601

Sprung from a limitless moment of desire\nl
That once had lodged in some abysmal heart.\nl
Passed was the heaviness of the eyeless dark\nl
And all the sorrow of the night was dead:\nl
Surprised by a blind joy with groping hands\nl
Like one who wakes to find his dreams were true,\nl
Into a happy misty twilit world\nl
Where all ran after light and joy and love\nl
She slipped; there far-off raptures drew more close\nl
