And deep anticipations of delight,\nl
For ever eager to be grasped and held,\nl
Were never grasped, yet breathed strange ecstasy.\nl
A pearl-winged indistinctness fleeting swam,\nl
An air that dared not suffer too much light.\nl
Vague fields were there, vague pastures gleamed, vague trees,\nl
Vague scenes dim-hearted in a drifting haze;\nl
Vague cattle white roamed glimmering through the mist;\nl
Vague spirits wandered with a bodiless cry,\nl
Vague melodies touched the soul and fled pursued\nl
Into harmonious distances unseized;\nl
Forms subtly elusive and half-luminous powers\nl
Wishing no goal for their unearthly course\nl
Strayed happily through vague ideal lands,\nl
Or floated without footing or their walk\nl
Left steps of reverie on sweet memory's ground;\nl
Or they paced to the mighty measure of their thoughts\nl
Led by a low far chanting of the gods.\nl
A ripple of gleaming wings crossed the far sky;\nl
Birds like pale-bosomed imaginations flew\nl
With low disturbing voices of desire,\nl
And half-heard lowings drew the listening ear,\nl
As if the Sun-god's brilliant kine were there\nl
Hidden in mist and passing towards the sun.\nl
These fugitive beings, these elusive shapes\nl
Were all that claimed the eye and met the soul,\nl
The natural inhabitants of that world.\nl
Page 602

But nothing there was fixed or stayed for long;\nl
No mortal feet could rest upon that soil,\nl
No breath of life lingered embodied there.\nl
In that fine chaos joy fled dancing past\nl
And beauty evaded settled line and form\nl
And hid its sense in mysteries of hue;\nl
Yet gladness ever repeated the same notes\nl
And gave the sense of an enduring world;\nl
There was a strange consistency of shapes,\nl
And the same thoughts were constant passers-by\nl
And all renewed unendingly its charm\nl
Alluring ever the expectant heart\nl
Like music that one always waits to hear,\nl
Like the recurrence of a haunting rhyme.\nl
One touched incessantly things never seized,\nl
A skirt of worlds invisibly divine.\nl
As if a trail of disappearing stars\nl
There showered upon the floating atmosphere\nl
Colours and lights and evanescent gleams\nl
That called to follow into a magic heaven,\nl
And in each cry that fainted on the ear\nl
There was the voice of an unrealised bliss.\nl
An adoration reigned in the yearning heart,\nl
A spirit of purity, an elusive presence\nl
Of faery beauty and ungrasped delight\nl
Whose momentary and escaping thrill,\nl
However unsubstantial to our flesh,\nl
And brief even in imperishableness,\nl
Much sweeter seemed than any rapture known\nl
Earth or all-conquering heaven can ever give.\nl
Heaven ever young and earth too firm and old\nl
Delay the heart by immobility:\nl
Their raptures of creation last too long,\nl
Their bold formations are too absolute;\nl
Carved by an anguish of divine endeavour\nl
They stand up sculptured on the eternal hills,\nl
Page 603

Or quarried from the living rocks of God\nl
Win immortality by perfect form.\nl
They are too intimate with eternal things:\nl
Vessels of infinite significances,\nl
They are too clear, too great, too meaningful;\nl
No mist or shadow soothes the vanquished sight,\nl
No soft penumbra of incertitude.\nl
These only touched a golden hem of bliss,\nl
The gleaming shoulder of some godlike hope,\nl
The flying feet of exquisite desires.\nl
On a slow trembling brink between night and day\nl
They shone like visitants from the morning star,\nl
Satisfied beginnings of perfection, first\nl
Tremulous imaginings of a heavenly world:\nl
They mingle in a passion of pursuit,\nl
Thrilled with a spray of joy too slight to tire.\nl
All in this world was shadowed forth, not limned,\nl
Like faces leaping on a fan of fire\nl
Or shapes of wonder in a tinted blur,\nl
Like fugitive landscapes painting silver mists.\nl
Here vision fled back from the sight alarmed,\nl
And sound sought refuge from the ear's surprise,\nl
And all experience was a hasty joy.\nl
The joys here snatched were half-forbidden things,\nl
Timorous soul-bridals delicately veiled\nl
As when a goddess' bosom dimly moves\nl
To first desire and her white soul transfigured,\nl
A glimmering Eden crossed by faery gleams,\nl
Trembles to expectation's fiery wand,\nl
But nothing is familiar yet with bliss.\nl
All things in this fair realm were heavenly strange\nl
In a fleeting gladness of untired delight,\nl
In an insistency of magic change.\nl
Past vanishing hedges, hurrying hints of fields,\nl
Mid swift escaping lanes that fled her feet\nl
Journeying she wished no end: as one through clouds\nl
Page 604

Travels upon a mountain ridge and hears\nl
Arising to him out of hidden depths\nl
Sound of invisible streams, she walked besieged\nl
By the illusion of a mystic space,\nl
A charm of bodiless touches felt and heard\nl
A sweetness as of voices high and dim\nl
Calling like travellers upon seeking winds\nl
Melodiously with an alluring cry.\nl
As if a music old yet ever new,\nl
Moving suggestions on her heart-strings dwelt,\nl
Thoughts that no habitation found, yet clung\nl
With passionate repetition to her mind,\nl
Desires that hurt not, happy only to live\nl
Always the same and always unfulfilled\nl
Sang in the breast like a celestial lyre.\nl
Thus all could last yet nothing ever be.\nl
In this beauty as of mind made visible,\nl
Dressed in its rays of wonder Satyavan\nl
Before her seemed the centre of its charm,\nl
Head of her loveliness of longing dreams\nl
And captain of the fancies of her soul.\nl
Even the dreadful majesty of Death's face\nl
And its sombre sadness could not darken nor slay\nl
The intangible lustre of those fleeting skies.\nl
The sombre Shadow sullen, implacable\nl
Made beauty and laughter more imperative;\nl
Enhanced by his grey, joy grew more bright and dear;\nl
His dark contrast edging ideal sight\nl
Deepened unuttered meanings to the heart;\nl
Pain grew a trembling undertone of bliss\nl
And transience immortality's floating hem,\nl
A moment's robe in which she looked more fair,\nl
Its antithesis sharpening her divinity.\nl
A comrade of the Ray and Mist and Flame,\nl
By a moon-bright face a brilliant moment drawn,\nl
Almost she seemed a thought mid floating thoughts,\nl
Page 605

Seen hardly by a visionary mind\nl
Amid the white inward musings of the soul.\nl
Half-vanquished by the dream-happiness around,\nl
Awhile she moved on an enchantment's soil,\nl
But still remained possessor of her soul.\nl
Above, her spirit in its mighty trance\nl
Saw all, but lived for its transcendent task,\nl
Immutable like a fixed eternal star.\nl
\rl{\fsc End of Canto One}
Page 606

\par
\ht Canto Two: The Gospel of Death and Vanity of the Ideal
\par
\sbigcap Then pealed the calm inexorable voice:\nl
Abolishing hope, cancelling life's golden truths,\nl
Fatal its accents smote the trembling air.\nl
That lovely world swam thin and frail, most like\nl
Some pearly evanescent farewell gleam\nl
On the faint verge of dusk in moonless eves.\nl
“Prisoner of Nature, many-visioned spirit,\nl
Thought's creature in the ideal's realm enjoying\nl
Thy unsubstantial immortality\nl
The subtle marvellous mind of man has feigned,\nl
This is the world from which thy yearnings came.\nl
When it would build eternity from the dust,\nl
Man's thought paints images illusion rounds;\nl
Prophesying glories it shall never see,\nl
It labours delicately among its dreams.\nl
Behold this fleeing of light-tasselled shapes,\nl
Aerial raiment of unbodied gods;\nl
A rapture of things that never can be born,\nl
Hope chants to hope a bright immortal choir;\nl
Cloud satisfies cloud, phantom to longing phantom\nl
Leans sweetly, sweetly is clasped or sweetly chased.\nl
This is the stuff from which the ideal is formed:\nl
Its builder is thought, its base the heart's desire,\nl
But nothing real answers to their call.\nl
The ideal dwells not in heaven, nor on the earth,\nl
A bright delirium of man's ardour of hope\nl
Drunk with the wine of its own fantasy.\nl
It is a brilliant shadow's dreamy trail.\nl
Thy vision's error builds the azure skies,\nl
Thy vision's error drew the rainbow's arch;\nl
Page 607

Thy mortal longing made for thee a soul.\nl
This angel in thy body thou callst love,\nl
Who shapes his wings from thy emotion's hues,\nl
In a ferment of thy body has been born\nl
And with the body that housed it it must die.\nl
It is a passion of thy yearning cells,\nl
It is flesh that calls to flesh to serve its lust;\nl
It is thy mind that seeks an answering mind\nl
And dreams awhile that it has found its mate;\nl
It is thy life that asks a human prop\nl
To uphold its weakness lonely in the world\nl
Or feeds its hunger on another's life.\nl
A beast of prey that pauses in its prowl,\nl
It crouches under a bush in splendid flower\nl
To seize a heart and body for its food:\nl
This beast thou dreamst immortal and a god.\nl
O human mind, vainly thou torturest\nl
An hour's delight to stretch through infinity's\nl
Long void and fill its formless, passionless gulfs,\nl
Persuading the insensible Abyss\nl
To lend eternity to perishing things,\nl
And trickst the fragile movements of thy heart\nl
With thy spirit's feint of immortality.\nl
All here emerges born from Nothingness;\nl
Encircled it lasts by the emptiness of Space,\nl
Awhile upheld by an unknowing Force,\nl
Then crumbles back into its parent Nought:\nl
Only the mute Alone can for ever be.\nl
In the Alone there is no room for love.\nl
In vain to clothe love's perishable mud\nl
Thou hast woven on the Immortals' borrowed loom\nl
The ideal's gorgeous and unfading robe.\nl
The ideal never yet was real made.\nl
Imprisoned in form that glory cannot live;\nl
Into a body shut it breathes no more.\nl
Intangible, remote, for ever pure,\nl
Page 608

A sovereign of its own brilliant void,\nl
Unwillingly it descends to earthly air\nl
To inhabit a white temple in man's heart:\nl
In his heart it shines rejected by his life.\nl
Immutable, bodiless, beautiful, grand and dumb,\nl
Immobile on its shining throne it sits;\nl
Dumb it receives his offering and his prayer.\nl
It has no voice to answer to his call,\nl
No feet that move, no hands to take his gifts:\nl
Aerial statue of the nude Idea,\nl
Virgin conception of a bodiless god,\nl
Its light stirs man the thinker to create\nl
An earthly semblance of diviner things.\nl
Its hued reflection falls upon man's acts;\nl
His institutions are its cenotaphs,\nl
He signs his dead conventions with its name;\nl
His virtues don the Ideal's skiey robe\nl
And a nimbus of the outline of its face:\nl
He hides their littleness with the divine Name.\nl
Yet insufficient is the bright pretence\nl
To screen their indigent and earthy make:\nl
Earth only is there and not some heavenly source.\nl
If heavens there are they are veiled in their own light,\nl
If a Truth eternal somewhere reigns unknown,\nl
It burns in a tremendous void of God;\nl
For truth shines far from the falsehoods of the world;\nl
How can the heavens come down to unhappy earth\nl
Or the eternal lodge in drifting time?\nl
How shall the Ideal tread earth's dolorous soil\nl
Where life is only a labour and a hope,\nl
A child of Matter and by Matter fed,\nl
A fire flaming low in Nature's grate,\nl
A wave that breaks upon a shore in Time,\nl
A journey's toilsome trudge with death for goal?\nl
The Avatars have lived and died in vain,\nl
Vain was the sage's thought, the prophet's voice;\nl
Page 609

In vain is seen the shining upward Way.\nl
Earth lies unchanged beneath the circling sun;\nl
She loves her fall and no omnipotence\nl
Her mortal imperfections can erase,\nl
Force on man's crooked ignorance Heaven's straight line\nl
Or colonise a world of death with gods.\nl
O traveller in the chariot of the Sun,\nl
High priestess in thy holy fancy's shrine\nl
Who with a magic ritual in earth's house\nl
Worshippest ideal and eternal love,\nl
What is this love thy thought has deified,\nl
This sacred legend and immortal myth?\nl
It is a conscious yearning of thy flesh,\nl
It is a glorious burning of thy nerves,\nl
A rose of dream-splendour petalling thy mind,\nl
A great red rapture and torture of thy heart.\nl
A sudden transfiguration of thy days,\nl
It passes and the world is as before.\nl
A ravishing edge of sweetness and of pain,\nl
A thrill in its yearning makes it seem divine,\nl
A golden bridge across the roar of the years,\nl
A cord tying thee to eternity.\nl
And yet how brief and frail! how soon is spent\nl
This treasure wasted by the gods on man,\nl
This happy closeness as of soul to soul,\nl
This honey of the body's companionship,\nl
This heightened joy, this ecstasy in the veins,\nl
This strange illumination of the sense!\nl
If Satyavan had lived, love would have died;\nl
But Satyavan is dead and love shall live\nl
A little while in thy sad breast, until\nl
His face and body fade on memory's wall\nl
Where other bodies, other faces come.\nl
When love breaks suddenly into the life\nl
At first man steps into a world of the sun;\nl
In his passion he feels his heavenly element:\nl
Page 610

But only a fine sunlit patch of earth\nl
The marvellous aspect took of heaven's outburst;\nl
The snake is there and the worm in the heart of the rose.\nl
A word, a moment's act can slay the god;\nl
Precarious is his immortality,\nl
He has a thousand ways to suffer and die.\nl
Love cannot live by heavenly food alone,\nl
Only on sap of earth can it survive.\nl
For thy passion was a sensual want refined,\nl
A hunger of the body and the heart;\nl
Thy want can tire and cease or turn elsewhere.\nl
Or love may meet a dire and pitiless end\nl
By bitter treason, or wrath with cruel wounds\nl
Separate, or thy unsatisfied will to others\nl
Depart when first love's joy lies stripped and slain:\nl
A dull indifference replaces fire\nl
Or an endearing habit imitates love:\nl
An outward and uneasy union lasts\nl
Or the routine of a life's compromise:\nl
Where once the seed of oneness had been cast\nl
Into a semblance of spiritual ground\nl
By a divine adventure of heavenly powers\nl
Two strive, constant associates without joy,\nl
Two egos straining in a single leash,\nl
Two minds divided by their jarring thoughts,\nl
Two spirits disjoined, for ever separate.\nl
Thus is the ideal falsified in man's world;\nl
Trivial or sombre, disillusion comes,\nl
Life's harsh reality stares at the soul:\nl
Heaven's hour adjourned flees into bodiless Time.\nl
Death saves thee from this and saves Satyavan:\nl
He now is safe, delivered from himself;\nl
He travels to silence and felicity.\nl
Call him not back to the treacheries of earth\nl
And the poor petty life of animal Man.\nl
In my vast tranquil spaces let him sleep\nl
Page 611

In harmony with the mighty hush of death\nl
Where love lies slumbering on the breast of peace.\nl
And thou, go back alone to thy frail world:\nl
Chastise thy heart with knowledge, unhood to see,\nl
Thy nature raised into clear living heights,\nl
The heaven-bird's view from unimagined peaks.\nl
For when thou givest thy spirit to a dream\nl
Soon hard necessity will smite thee awake:\nl
Purest delight began and it must end.\nl
Thou too shalt know, thy heart no anchor swinging,\nl
Thy cradled soul moored in eternal seas.\nl
Vain are the cycles of thy brilliant mind.\nl
Renounce, forgetting joy and hope and tears,\nl
Thy passionate nature in the bosom profound\nl
Of a happy Nothingness and worldless Calm,\nl
Delivered into my mysterious rest.\nl
One with my fathomless Nihil all forget.\nl
Forget thy fruitless spirit's waste of force,\nl
Forget the weary circle of thy birth,\nl
Forget the joy and the struggle and the pain,\nl
The vague spiritual quest which first began\nl
When worlds broke forth like clusters of fire-flowers,\nl
And great burning thoughts voyaged through the sky of mind\nl
And Time and its aeons crawled across the vasts\nl
And souls emerged into mortality.”\nl
\sparn But Savitri replied to the dark Power:\nl
“A dangerous music now thou findst, O Death,\nl
Melting thy speech into harmonious pain,\nl
And flut'st alluringly to tired hopes\nl
Thy falsehoods mingled with sad strains of truth.\nl
But I forbid thy voice to slay my soul.\nl
My love is not a hunger of the heart,\nl
My love is not a craving of the flesh;\nl
It came to me from God, to God returns.\nl
Even in all that life and man have marred,\nl
A whisper of divinity still is heard,\nl
Page 612

A breath is felt from the eternal spheres.\nl
Allowed by Heaven and wonderful to man\nl
A sweet fire-rhythm of passion chants to love.\nl
There is a hope in its wild infinite cry;\nl
It rings with callings from forgotten heights,\nl
And when its strains are hushed to high-winged souls\nl
In their empyrean, its burning breath\nl
Survives beyond, the rapturous core of suns\nl
That flame for ever pure in skies unseen,\nl
A voice of the eternal Ecstasy.\nl
One day I shall behold my great sweet world\nl
Put off the dire disguises of the gods,\nl
Unveil from terror and disrobe from sin.\nl
Appeased we shall draw near our mother's face,\nl
We shall cast our candid souls upon her lap;\nl
Then shall we clasp the ecstasy we chase,\nl
Then shall we shudder with the long-sought god,\nl
Then shall we find Heaven's unexpected strain.\nl
Not only is there hope for godheads pure;\nl
The violent and darkened deities\nl
Leaped down from the one breast in rage to find\nl
What the white gods had missed: they too are safe;\nl
A mother's eyes are on them and her arms\nl
Stretched out in love desire her rebel sons.\nl
One who came love and lover and beloved\nl
Eternal, built himself a wondrous field\nl
And wove the measures of a marvellous dance.\nl
There in its circles and its magic turns\nl
Attracted he arrives, repelled he flees.\nl
In the wild devious promptings of his mind\nl
He tastes the honey of tears and puts off joy\nl
Repenting, and has laughter and has wrath,\nl
And both are a broken music of the soul\nl
Which seeks out reconciled its heavenly rhyme.\nl
Ever he comes to us across the years\nl
Bearing a new sweet face that is the old.\nl
Page 613

His bliss laughs to us or it calls concealed\nl
Like a far-heard unseen entrancing flute\nl
From moonlit branches in the throbbing woods,\nl
Tempting our angry search and passionate pain.\nl
Disguised the Lover seeks and draws our souls.\nl
He named himself for me, grew Satyavan.\nl
For we were man and woman from the first,\nl
The twin souls born from one undying fire.\nl
Did he not dawn on me in other stars?\nl
How has he through the thickets of the world\nl
Pursued me like a lion in the night\nl
And come upon me suddenly in the ways\nl
And seized me with his glorious golden leap!\nl
Unsatisfied he yearned for me through time,\nl
Sometimes with wrath and sometimes with sweet peace\nl
Desiring me since first the world began.\nl
He rose like a wild wave out of the floods\nl
And dragged me helpless into seas of bliss.\nl
Out of my curtained past his arms arrive;\nl
They have touched me like the soft persuading wind,\nl
They have plucked me like a glad and trembling flower,\nl
And clasped me happily burned in ruthless flame.\nl
I too have found him charmed in lovely forms\nl
And run delighted to his distant voice\nl
And pressed to him past many dreadful bars.\nl
If there is a yet happier greater god,\nl
Let him first wear the face of Satyavan\nl
And let his soul be one with him I love;\nl
So let him seek me that I may desire.\nl
For only one heart beats within my breast\nl
And one god sits there throned. Advance, O Death,\nl
Beyond the phantom beauty of this world;\nl
For of its citizens I am not one.\nl
I cherish God the Fire, not God the Dream.”\nl
But Death once more inflicted on her heart\nl
The majesty of his calm and dreadful voice:\nl
Page 614

“A bright hallucination are thy thoughts.\nl
A prisoner haled by a spiritual cord,\nl
Of thy own sensuous will the ardent slave,\nl
Thou sendest eagle-poised to meet the sun\nl
Words winged with the red splendour of thy heart.\nl
But knowledge dwells not in the passionate heart;\nl
The heart's words fall back unheard from Wisdom's throne.\nl
Vain is thy longing to build heaven on earth.\nl
Artificer of Ideal and Idea,\nl
Mind, child of Matter in the womb of Life,\nl
To higher levels persuades his parents' steps:\nl
Inapt, they follow ill the daring guide.\nl
But Mind, a glorious traveller in the sky,\nl
Walks lamely on the earth with footsteps slow;\nl
Hardly he can mould the life's rebellious stuff,\nl
Hardly can he hold the galloping hooves of sense:\nl
His thoughts look straight into the very heavens;\nl
They draw their gold from a celestial mine,\nl
His acts work painfully a common ore.\nl
All thy high dreams were made by Matter's mind\nl
To solace its dull work in Matter's jail,\nl
Its only house where it alone seems true.\nl
A solid image of reality\nl
Carved out of being to prop the works of Time,\nl
Matter on the firm earth sits strong and sure.\nl
It is the first-born of created things,\nl
It stands the last when mind and life are slain,\nl
And if it ended all would cease to be.\nl
All else is only its outcome or its phase:\nl
Thy soul is a brief flower by the gardener Mind\nl
Created in thy matter's terrain plot;\nl
It perishes with the plant on which it grows,\nl
For from earth's sap it draws its heavenly hue:\nl
Thy thoughts are gleams that pass on Matter's verge,\nl
Thy life a lapsing wave on Matter's sea.\nl
A careful steward of Truth's limited means,\nl
Page 615

Treasuring her founded facts from the squandering Power,\nl
It tethers mind to the tent-posts of sense,\nl
To a leaden grey routine clamps Life's caprice\nl
And ties all creatures with the cords of Law.\nl
A vessel of transmuting alchemies,\nl
A glue that sticks together mind and life,\nl
If Matter fails, all crumbling cracks and falls.\nl
All upon Matter stands as on a rock.\nl
Yet this security and guarantor\nl
Pressed for credentials an impostor proves:\nl
A cheat of substance where no substance is,\nl
An appearance and a symbol and a nought,\nl
Its forms have no original right to birth:\nl
Its aspect of a fixed stability\nl
Is the cover of a captive motion's swirl,\nl
An order of the steps of Energy's dance\nl
Whose footmarks leave for ever the same signs,\nl
A concrete face of unsubstantial Time,\nl
A trickle dotting the emptiness of Space:\nl
A stable-seeming movement without change,\nl
Yet change arrives and the last change is death.\nl
What seemed most real once, is Nihil's show.\nl
Its figures are snares that trap and prison the sense;\nl
The beginningless Void was its artificer:\nl
Nothing is there but aspects limned by Chance\nl
And seeming shapes of seeming Energy.\nl
All by Death's mercy breathe and live awhile,\nl
All think and act by the Inconscient's grace.\nl
Addict of the roseate luxury of thy thoughts,\nl
Turn not thy gaze within thyself to look\nl
At visions in the gleaming crystal, Mind,\nl
Close not thy lids to dream the forms of Gods.\nl
At last to open thy eyes consent and see\nl
The stuff of which thou and the world are made.\nl
Inconscient in the dumb inconscient Void\nl
Inexplicably a moving world sprang forth:\nl
Page 616

Awhile secure, happily insensible,\nl
It could not rest content with its own truth.\nl
For something on its nescient breast was born\nl
Condemned to see and know, to feel and love,\nl
It watched its acts, imagined a soul within;\nl
It groped for truth and dreamed of Self and God.\nl
When all unconscious was, then all was well.\nl
I, Death, was king and kept my regal state,\nl
Designing my unwilled, unerring plan,\nl
Creating with a calm insentient heart.\nl
In my sovereign power of unreality\nl
Obliging nothingness to take a form,\nl
Infallibly my blind unthinking force\nl
Making by chance a fixity like fate's,\nl
By whim the formulas of Necessity,\nl
Founded on the hollow ground of the Inane\nl
The sure bizarrerie of Nature's scheme.\nl
I curved the vacant ether into Space;\nl
A huge expanding and contracting Breath\nl
Harboured the fires of the universe:\nl
I struck out the supreme original spark\nl
And spread its sparse ranked armies through the Inane,\nl
Manufactured the stars from the occult radiances,\nl
Marshalled the platoons of the invisible dance;\nl
I formed earth's beauty out of atom and gas,\nl
And built from chemic plasm the living man.\nl
Then Thought came in and spoiled the harmonious world:\nl
Matter began to hope and think and feel,\nl
Tissue and nerve bore joy and agony.\nl
The inconscient cosmos strove to learn its task;\nl
An ignorant personal God was born in Mind\nl
And to understand invented reason's law,\nl
The impersonal Vast throbbed back to man's desire,\nl
A trouble rocked the great world's blind still heart\nl
And Nature lost her wide immortal calm.\nl
Thus came this warped incomprehensible scene\nl
Page 617

Of souls emmeshed in life's delight and pain\nl
And Matter's sleep and Mind's mortality,\nl
Of beings in Nature's prison waiting death\nl
And consciousness left in seeking ignorance\nl
And evolution's slow arrested plan.\nl
This is the world in which thou mov'st, astray\nl
In the tangled pathways of the human mind,\nl
In the issueless circling of thy human life,\nl
Searching for thy soul and thinking God is here.\nl
But where is room for soul or place for God\nl
In the brute immensity of a machine?\nl
A transient Breath thou takest for thy soul,\nl
Born from a gas, a plasm, a sperm, a gene,\nl
A magnified image of man's mind for God,\nl
A shadow of thyself thrown upon Space.\nl
Interposed between the upper and nether Void,\nl
Thy consciousness reflects the world around\nl
In the distorting mirror of Ignorance\nl
Or upwards turns to catch imagined stars.\nl
Or if a half-Truth is playing with the earth\nl
Throwing its light on a dark shadowy ground,\nl
It touches only and leaves a luminous smudge.\nl
Immortality thou claimest for thy spirit,\nl
But immortality for imperfect man,\nl
A god who hurts himself at every step,\nl
Would be a cycle of eternal pain.\nl
Wisdom and love thou claimest as thy right;\nl
But knowledge in this world is error's mate,\nl
A brilliant procuress of Nescience,\nl
And human love a posturer on earth-stage\nl
Who imitates with verve a faery dance.\nl
An extract pressed from hard experience,\nl
Man's knowledge casked in the barrels of Memory\nl
Has the harsh savour of a mortal draught:\nl
A sweet secretion from the erotic glands\nl
Flattering and torturing the burning nerves,\nl
Page 618

Love is a honey and poison in the breast\nl
Drunk by it as the nectar of the gods.\nl
Earth's human wisdom is no great-browed power,\nl
And love no gleaming angel from the skies;\nl
If they aspire beyond earth's dullard air,\nl
Arriving sunwards with frail waxen wings,\nl
How high could reach that forced unnatural flight?\nl
But not on earth can divine wisdom reign\nl
And not on earth can divine love be found;\nl
Heaven-born, only in heaven can they live;\nl
Or else there too perhaps they are shining dreams.\nl
Nay, is not all thou art and doest a dream?\nl
Thy mind and life are tricks of Matter's force.\nl
If thy mind seems to thee a radiant sun,\nl
If thy life runs a swift and glorious stream,\nl
This is the illusion of thy mortal heart\nl
Dazzled by a ray of happiness or light.\nl
Impotent to live by their own right divine,\nl
Convinced of their brilliant unreality,\nl
When their supporting ground is cut away,\nl
These children of Matter into Matter die.\nl
Even Matter vanishes into Energy's vague\nl
And Energy is a motion of old Nought.\nl
How shall the Ideal's unsubstantial hues\nl
Be painted stiff on earth's vermilion blur,\nl
A dream within a dream come doubly true?\nl
How shall the will-o'-the-wisp become a star?\nl
The Ideal is a malady of thy mind,\nl
A bright delirium of thy speech and thought,\nl
A strange wine of beauty lifting thee to false sight.\nl
A noble fiction of thy yearnings made,\nl
Thy human imperfection it must share:\nl
Its forms in Nature disappoint the heart,\nl
And never shall it find its heavenly shape\nl
And never can it be fulfilled in Time.\nl
O soul misled by the splendour of thy thoughts,\nl
Page 619

O earthly creature with thy dream of heaven,\nl
Obey, resigned and still, the earthly law.\nl
Accept the brief light that falls upon thy days;\nl
Take what thou canst of Life's permitted joy;\nl
Submitting to the ordeal of fate's scourge\nl
Suffer what thou must of toil and grief and care.\nl
There shall approach silencing thy passionate heart\nl
My long calm night of everlasting sleep:\nl
There into the hush from which thou cam'st retire.”\nl
\rl{\fsc End of Canto Two}
Page 620

\par
\ht Canto Three: The Debate of Love and Death
\par
\sbigcap A sad destroying cadence the voice sank;\nl
It seemed to lead the advancing march of Life\nl
Into some still original Inane.\nl
But Savitri answered to almighty Death:\nl
“O dark-browed sophist of the universe\nl
Who veilst the Real with its own Idea,\nl
Hiding with brute objects Nature's living face,\nl
Masking eternity with thy dance of death,\nl
Thou hast woven the ignorant mind into a screen\nl
And made of Thought error's purveyor and scribe,\nl
And a false witness of mind's servant sense.\nl
An aesthete of the sorrow of the world,\nl
Champion of a harsh and sad philosophy\nl
Thou hast used words to shutter out the Light\nl
And called in Truth to vindicate a lie.\nl
A lying reality is falsehood's crown\nl
And a perverted truth her richest gem.\nl
O Death, thou speakest truth but truth that slays,\nl
I answer to thee with the Truth that saves.\nl
A traveller new-discovering himself,\nl
One made of Matter's world his starting-point,\nl
He made of Nothingness his living-room\nl
And Night a process of the eternal light\nl
And death a spur towards immortality.\nl
God wrapped his head from sight in Matter's cowl,\nl
His consciousness dived into inconscient depths,\nl
All-Knowledge seemed a huge dark Nescience;\nl
Infinity wore a boundless zero's form.\nl
His abysms of bliss became insensible deeps,\nl
Eternity a blank spiritual Vast.\nl
Annulling an original nullity\nl
Page 621

The Timeless took its ground in emptiness\nl
And drew the figure of a universe,\nl
That the spirit might adventure into Time\nl
And wrestle with adamant Necessity\nl
And the soul pursue a cosmic pilgrimage.\nl
A spirit moved in black immensities\nl
And built a Thought in ancient Nothingness;\nl
A soul was lit in God's tremendous Void,\nl
A secret labouring glow of nascent fire.\nl
In Nihil's gulf his mighty Puissance wrought;\nl
She swung her formless motion into shapes,\nl
Made Matter the body of the Bodiless.\nl
Infant and dim the eternal Mights awoke.\nl
In inert Matter breathed a slumbering Life,\nl
In a subconscient Life Mind lay asleep;\nl
In waking Life it stretched its giant limbs\nl
To shake from it the torpor of its drowse;\nl
A senseless substance quivered into sense,\nl
The world's heart commenced to beat, its eyes to see,\nl
In the crowded dumb vibrations of a brain\nl
Thought fumbled in a ring to find itself,\nl
Discovered speech and fed the new-born Word\nl
That bridged with spans of light the world's ignorance.\nl
In waking Mind, the Thinker built his house.\nl
A reasoning animal willed and planned and sought;\nl
He stood erect among his brute compeers,\nl
He built life new, measured the universe,\nl
Opposed his fate and wrestled with unseen Powers,\nl
Conquered and used the laws that rule the world,\nl
And hoped to ride the heavens and reach the stars,\nl
A master of his huge environment.\nl
Now through Mind's windows stares the demigod\nl
Hidden behind the curtains of man's soul:\nl
He has seen the Unknown, looked on Truth's veilless face;\nl
A ray has touched him from the eternal sun;\nl
Motionless, voiceless in foreseeing depths,\nl
Page 622

He stands awake in Supernature's light\nl
And sees a glory of arisen wings\nl
And sees the vast descending might of God.\nl
\sparn “O Death, thou lookst on an unfinished world\nl
Assailed by thee and of its road unsure,\nl
Peopled by imperfect minds and ignorant lives,\nl
And sayest God is not and all is vain.\nl
How shall the child already be the man?\nl
Because he is infant, shall he never grow?\nl
Because he is ignorant, shall he never learn?\nl
In a small fragile seed a great tree lurks,\nl
In a tiny gene a thinking being is shut;\nl
A little element in a little sperm,\nl
It grows and is a conqueror and a sage.\nl
Then wilt thou spew out, Death, God's mystic truth,\nl
Deny the occult spiritual miracle?\nl
Still wilt thou say there is no spirit, no God?\nl
A mute material Nature wakes and sees;\nl
She has invented speech, unveiled a will.\nl
Something there waits beyond towards which she strives,\nl
Something surrounds her into which she grows:\nl
To uncover the spirit, to change back into God,\nl
To exceed herself is her transcendent task.\nl
In God concealed the world began to be,\nl
Tardily it travels towards manifest God:\nl
Our imperfection towards perfection toils,\nl
The body is the chrysalis of a soul:\nl
The infinite holds the finite in its arms,\nl
Time travels towards revealed eternity.\nl
A miracle structure of the eternal Mage,\nl
Matter its mystery hides from its own eyes,\nl
A scripture written out in cryptic signs,\nl
An occult document of the All-Wonderful's art.\nl
All here bears witness to his secret might,\nl
In all we feel his presence and his power.\nl
A blaze of his sovereign glory is the sun,\nl
Page 623

A glory is the gold and glimmering moon,\nl
A glory is his dream of purple sky.\nl
A march of his greatness are the wheeling stars.\nl
His laughter of beauty breaks out in green trees,\nl
His moments of beauty triumph in a flower;\nl
The blue sea's chant, the rivulet's wandering voice\nl
Are murmurs falling from the Eternal's harp.\nl
This world is God fulfilled in outwardness.\nl
His ways challenge our reason and our sense;\nl
By blind brute movements of an ignorant Force,\nl
By means we slight as small, obscure or base,\nl
A greatness founded upon little things,\nl
He has built a world in the unknowing Void.\nl
His forms he has massed from infinitesimal dust;\nl
His marvels are built from insignificant things.\nl
If mind is crippled, life untaught and crude,\nl
If brutal masks are there and evil acts,\nl
They are incidents of his vast and varied plot,\nl
His great and dangerous drama's needed steps;\nl
He makes with these and all his passion-play,\nl
A play and yet no play but the deep scheme\nl
Of a transcendent Wisdom finding ways\nl
To meet her Lord in the shadow and the Night:\nl
Above her is the vigil of the stars;\nl
Watched by a solitary Infinitude\nl
She embodies in dumb Matter the Divine,\nl
In symbol minds and lives the Absolute.\nl
A miracle-monger her mechanical craft;\nl
Matter's machine worked out the laws of thought,\nl
Life's engines served the labour of a soul:\nl
The Mighty Mother her creation wrought,\nl
A huge caprice self-bound by iron laws,\nl
And shut God into an enigmatic world:\nl
She lulled the Omniscient into nescient sleep,\nl
Omnipotence on Inertia's back she drove,\nl
Trod perfectly with divine unconscious steps\nl
Page 624

The enormous circle of her wonder-works.\nl
Immortality assured itself by death;\nl
The Eternal's face was seen through drifts of Time.\nl
His knowledge he disguised as Ignorance,\nl
His Good he sowed in Evil's monstrous bed,\nl
Made error a door by which Truth could enter in,\nl
His plant of bliss watered with Sorrow's tears.\nl
A thousand aspects point back to the One;\nl
A dual Nature covered the Unique.\nl
In this meeting of the Eternal's mingling masques,\nl
This tangle-dance of passionate contraries\nl
Locking like lovers in a forbidden embrace\nl
The quarrel of their lost identity,\nl
Through this wrestle and wrangle of the extremes of Power\nl
Earth's million roads struggled towards deity.\nl
All stumbled on behind a stumbling Guide,\nl
Yet every stumble is a needed pace\nl
On unknown routes to an unknowable goal.\nl
All blundered and straggled towards the One Divine.\nl
As if transmuted by a titan spell\nl
The eternal Powers assumed a dubious face:\nl
Idols of an oblique divinity,\nl
They wore the heads of animal or troll,\nl
Assumed ears of the faun, the satyr's hoof,\nl
Or harboured the demoniac in their gaze:\nl
A crooked maze they made of thinking mind,\nl
They suffered a metamorphosis of the heart,\nl
Admitting bacchant revellers from the Night\nl
Into its sanctuary of delights,\nl
As in a Dionysian masquerade.\nl
On the highways, in the gardens of the world\nl
They wallowed oblivious of their divine parts,\nl
As drunkards of a dire Circean wine\nl
Or a child who sprawls and sports in Nature's mire.\nl
Even wisdom, hewer of the roads of God,\nl
Is a partner in the deep disastrous game:\nl
Page 625

Lost is the pilgrim's wallet and the scrip,\nl
She fails to read the map and watch the star.\nl
A poor self-righteous virtue is her stock\nl
And reason's pragmatic grope or abstract sight,\nl
Or the technique of a brief hour's success\nl
She teaches, an usher in utility's school.\nl
On the ocean surface of vast Consciousness\nl
Small thoughts in shoals are fished up into a net\nl
But the great truths escape her narrow cast;\nl
Guarded from vision by creation's depths,\nl
Obscure they swim in blind enormous gulfs\nl
Safe from the little sounding leads of mind,\nl
Too far for the puny diver's shallow plunge.\nl
Our mortal vision peers with ignorant eyes;\nl
It has no gaze on the deep heart of things.\nl
Our knowledge walks leaning on Error's staff,\nl
A worshipper of false dogmas and false gods,\nl
Or fanatic of a fierce intolerant creed\nl
Or a seeker doubting every truth he finds,\nl
A sceptic facing Light with adamant No\nl
Or chilling the heart with dry ironic smile,\nl
A cynic stamping out the god in man;\nl
A darkness wallows in the paths of Time\nl
Or lifts its giant head to blot the stars;\nl
It makes a cloud of the interpreting mind\nl
And intercepts the oracles of the Sun.\nl
Yet Light is there; it stands at Nature's doors:\nl
It holds a torch to lead the traveller in.\nl
It waits to be kindled in our secret cells;\nl
It is a star lighting an ignorant sea,\nl
A lamp upon our poop piercing the night.\nl
As knowledge grows Light flames up from within:\nl
It is a shining warrior in the mind,\nl
An eagle of dreams in the divining heart,\nl
An armour in the fight, a bow of God.\nl
Then larger dawns arrive and Wisdom's pomps\nl
Page 626

Cross through the being's dim half-lighted fields;\nl
Philosophy climbs up Thought's cloud-bank peaks\nl
And Science tears out Nature's occult powers,\nl
Enormous djinns who serve a dwarf's small needs,\nl
Exposes the sealed minutiae of her art\nl
And conquers her by her own captive force.\nl
On heights unreached by mind's most daring soar,\nl
Upon a dangerous edge of failing Time\nl
The soul draws back into its deathless Self;\nl
Man's knowledge becomes God's supernal Ray.\nl
There is the mystic realm whence leaps the power\nl
Whose fire burns in the eyes of seer and sage;\nl
A lightning flash of visionary sight,\nl
It plays upon an inward verge of mind:\nl
Thought silenced gazes into a brilliant Void.\nl
A voice comes down from mystic unseen peaks:\nl
A cry of splendour from a mouth of storm,\nl
It is the voice that speaks to night's profound,\nl
It is the thunder and the flaming call.\nl
Above the planes that climb from nescient earth,\nl
A hand is lifted towards the Invisible's realm,\nl
Beyond the superconscient's blinding line\nl
And plucks away the screens of the Unknown;\nl
A spirit within looks into the Eternal's eyes.\nl
It hears the Word to which our hearts were deaf,\nl
It sees through the blaze in which our thoughts grew blind;\nl
It drinks from the naked breasts of glorious Truth,\nl
It learns the secrets of eternity.\nl
Thus all was plunged into the riddling Night,\nl
Thus all is raised to meet a dazzling Sun.\nl
O Death, this is the mystery of thy reign.\nl
In earth's anomalous and magic field\nl
Carried in its aimless journey by the sun\nl
Mid the forced marches of the great dumb stars,\nl
A darkness occupied the fields of God,\nl
And Matter's world was governed by thy shape.\nl
Page 627

Thy mask has covered the Eternal's face,\nl
The Bliss that made the world has fallen asleep.\nl
Abandoned in the Vast she slumbered on:\nl
An evil transmutation overtook\nl
Her members till she knew herself no more.\nl
Only through her creative slumber flit\nl
Frail memories of the joy and beauty meant\nl
Under the sky's blue laugh mid green-scarfed trees\nl
And happy squanderings of scents and hues,\nl
In the field of the golden promenade of the sun\nl
And the vigil of the dream-light of the stars,\nl
Amid high meditating heads of hills,\nl
On the bosom of voluptuous rain-kissed earth\nl
And by the sapphire tumblings of the sea.\nl
But now the primal innocence is lost\nl
And Death and Ignorance govern the mortal world\nl
And Nature's visage wears a greyer hue.\nl
Earth still has kept her early charm and grace,\nl
The grandeur and the beauty still are hers,\nl
But veiled is the divine Inhabitant.\nl
The souls of men have wandered from the Light\nl
And the great Mother turns away her face.\nl
The eyes of the creatrix Bliss are closed\nl
And sorrow's touch has found her in her dreams.\nl
As she turns and tosses on her bed of Void,\nl
Because she cannot wake and find herself\nl
And cannot build again her perfect shape,\nl
Oblivious of her nature and her state,\nl
Forgetting her instinct of felicity,\nl
Forgetting to create a world of joy,\nl
She weeps and makes her creatures' eyes to weep;\nl
Testing with sorrow's edge her children's breasts,\nl
She spends on life's vain waste of hope and toil\nl
The poignant luxury of grief and tears.\nl
In the nightmare change of her half-conscious dream,\nl
Tortured herself and torturing by her touch,\nl
Page 628

She comes to our hearts and bodies and our lives\nl
Wearing a hard and cruel mask of pain.\nl
Our nature twisted by the abortive birth\nl
Returns wry answers to life's questioning shocks,\nl
An acrid relish finds in the world's pangs,\nl
Drinks the sharp wine of grief's perversity.\nl
A curse is laid on the pure joy of life:\nl
Delight, God's sweetest sign and Beauty's twin,\nl
Dreaded by aspiring saint and austere sage,\nl
Is shunned, a dangerous and ambiguous cheat,\nl
A specious trick of an infernal Power\nl
It tempts the soul to its self-hurt and fall.\nl
A puritan God made pleasure a poisonous fruit,\nl
Or red drug in the market-place of Death,\nl
And sin the child of Nature's ecstasy.\nl
Yet every creature hunts for happiness,\nl
Buys with harsh pangs or tears by violence\nl
From the dull breast of the inanimate globe\nl
Some fragment or some broken shard of bliss.\nl
Even joy itself becomes a poisonous draught;\nl
Its hunger is made a dreadful hook of Fate.\nl
All means are held good to catch a single beam,\nl
Eternity sacrificed for a moment's bliss:\nl
Yet for joy and not for sorrow earth was made\nl
And not as a dream in endless suffering Time.\nl
Although God made the world for his delight,\nl
An ignorant Power took charge and seemed his Will\nl
And Death's deep falsity has mastered Life.\nl
All grew a play of Chance simulating Fate.\nl

\spar “A secret air of pure felicity\nl
Deep like a sapphire heaven our spirits breathe;\nl
Our hearts and bodies feel its obscure call,\nl
Our senses grope for it and touch and lose.\nl
If this withdrew, the world would sink in the Void;\nl
If this were not, nothing could move or live.\nl
Page 629

A hidden Bliss is at the root of things.\nl
A mute Delight regards Time's countless works:\nl
To house God's joy in things Space gave wide room,\nl
To house God's joy in self our souls were born.\nl
This universe an old enchantment guards;\nl
Its objects are carved cups of World-Delight\nl
Whose charmed wine is some deep soul's rapture-drink:\nl
The All-Wonderful has packed heaven with his dreams,\nl
He has made blank ancient Space his marvel-house;\nl
He spilled his spirit into Matter's signs:\nl
His fires of grandeur burn in the great sun,\nl
He glides through heaven shimmering in the moon;\nl
He is beauty carolling in the fields of sound;\nl
He chants the stanzas of the odes of Wind;\nl
He is silence watching in the stars at night;\nl
He wakes at dawn and calls from every bough,\nl
Lies stunned in the stone and dreams in flower and tree.\nl
Even in this labour and dolour of Ignorance,\nl
On the hard perilous ground of difficult earth,\nl
In spite of death and evil circumstance\nl
A will to live persists, a joy to be.\nl
There is a joy in all that meets the sense,\nl
A joy in all experience of the soul,\nl
A joy in evil and a joy in good,\nl
A joy in virtue and a joy in sin:\nl
Indifferent to the threat of Karmic law,\nl
Joy dares to grow upon forbidden soil,\nl
Its sap runs through the plant and flowers of Pain:\nl
It thrills with the drama of fate and tragic doom,\nl
It tears its food from sorrow and ecstasy,\nl
On danger and difficulty whets its strength;\nl
It wallows with the reptile and the worm\nl
And lifts its head, an equal of the stars;\nl
It shares the faeries' dance, dines with the gnome:\nl
It basks in the light and heat of many suns,\nl
The sun of Beauty and the sun of Power\nl
Page 630

Flatter and foster it with golden beams;\nl
It grows towards the Titan and the God.\nl
On earth it lingers drinking its deep fill,\nl
Through the symbol of her pleasure and her pain,\nl
Of the grapes of Heaven and the flowers of the Abyss,\nl
Of the flame-stabs and the torment-craft of Hell\nl
And dim fragments of the glory of Paradise.\nl
In the small paltry pleasures of man's life,\nl
In his petty passions and joys it finds a taste,\nl
A taste in tears and torture of broken hearts,\nl
In the crown of gold and in the crown of thorns,\nl
In life's nectar of sweetness and its bitter wine.\nl
All being it explores for unknown bliss,\nl
Sounds all experience for things new and strange.\nl
Life brings into the earthly creature's days\nl
A tongue of glory from a brighter sphere:\nl
It deepens in his musings and his Art,\nl
It leaps at the splendour of some perfect word,\nl
It exults in his high resolves and noble deeds,\nl
Wanders in his errors, dares the abyss's brink,\nl
It climbs in his climbings, wallows in his fall.\nl
Angel and demon brides his chamber share,\nl
Possessors or competitors for life's heart.\nl
To the enjoyer of the cosmic scene\nl
His greatness and his littleness equal are,\nl
His magnanimity and meanness hues\nl
Cast on some neutral background of the gods:\nl
The Artist's skill he admires who planned it all.\nl
But not for ever endures this danger game:\nl
Beyond the earth, but meant for delivered earth,\nl
Wisdom and joy prepare their perfect crown;\nl
Truth superhuman calls to thinking man.\nl
At last the soul turns to eternal things,\nl
In every shrine it cries for the clasp of God.\nl
Then is there played the crowning Mystery,\nl
Then is achieved the longed-for miracle.\nl
Page 631

Immortal Bliss her wide celestial eyes\nl
Opens on the stars, she stirs her mighty limbs;\nl
Time thrills to the sapphics of her amour-song\nl
And Space fills with a white beatitude.\nl
Then leaving to its grief the human heart,\nl
Abandoning speech and the name-determined realms,\nl
Through a gleaming far-seen sky of wordless thought,\nl
Through naked thought-free heavens of absolute sight,\nl
She climbs to the summits where the unborn Idea\nl
Remembering the future that must be\nl
Looks down upon the works of labouring Force,\nl
Immutable above the world it made.\nl
In the vast golden laughter of Truth's sun\nl
Like a great heaven-bird on a motionless sea\nl
Is poised her winged ardour of creative joy\nl
On the still deep of the Eternal's peace.\nl
This was the aim, this the supernal Law,\nl
Nature's allotted task when beauty-drenched\nl
In dim mist-waters of inconscient sleep,\nl
Out of the Void this grand creation rose,—\nl
For this the Spirit came into the Abyss\nl
And charged with its power Matter's unknowing force,\nl
In Night's bare session to cathedral Light,\nl
In Death's realm repatriate immortality.\nl
A mystic slow transfiguration works.\nl
All our earth starts from mud and ends in sky,\nl
And Love that was once an animal's desire,\nl
Then a sweet madness in the rapturous heart,\nl
An ardent comradeship in the happy mind,\nl
Becomes a wide spiritual yearning's space.\nl
A lonely soul passions for the Alone,\nl
The heart that loved man thrills to the love of God,\nl
A body is his chamber and his shrine.\nl
Then is our being rescued from separateness;\nl
All is itself, all is new-felt in God:\nl
A Lover leaning from his cloister's door\nl
Page 632

Gathers the whole world into his single breast.\nl
Then shall the business fail of Night and Death:\nl
When unity is won, when strife is lost\nl
And all is known and all is clasped by Love\nl
Who would turn back to ignorance and pain?\nl
\sparn “O Death, I have triumphed over thee within;\nl
I quiver no more with the assault of grief;\nl
A mighty calmness seated deep within\nl
Has occupied my body and my sense:\nl
It takes the world's grief and transmutes to strength,\nl
It makes the world's joy one with the joy of God.\nl
My love eternal sits throned on God's calm;\nl
For Love must soar beyond the very heavens\nl
And find its secret sense ineffable;\nl
It must change its human ways to ways divine,\nl
Yet keep its sovereignty of earthly bliss.\nl
O Death, not for my heart's sweet poignancy\nl
Nor for my happy body's bliss alone\nl
I have claimed from thee the living Satyavan,\nl
But for his work and mine, our sacred charge.\nl
Our lives are God's messengers beneath the stars;\nl
To dwell under death's shadow they have come\nl
Tempting God's light to earth for the ignorant race,\nl
His love to fill the hollow in men's hearts,\nl
His bliss to heal the unhappiness of the world.\nl
For I, the woman, am the force of God,\nl
He the Eternal's delegate soul in man.\nl
My will is greater than thy law, O Death;\nl
My love is stronger than the bonds of Fate:\nl
Our love is the heavenly seal of the Supreme.\nl
I guard that seal against thy rending hands.\nl
Love must not cease to live upon the earth;\nl
For Love is the bright link twixt earth and heaven,\nl
Love is the far Transcendent's angel here;\nl
Love is man's lien on the Absolute.”\nl
But to the woman Death the god replied,\nl
Page 633

With the ironic laughter of his voice\nl
Discouraging the labour of the stars:\nl
“Even so men cheat the Truth with splendid thoughts.\nl
Thus wilt thou hire the glorious charlatan, Mind,\nl
To weave from his Ideal's gossamer air\nl
A fine raiment for thy body's nude desires\nl
And thy heart's clutching greedy passion clothe?\nl
Daub not the web of life with magic hues:\nl
Make rather thy thought a plain and faithful glass\nl
Reflecting Matter and mortality,\nl
And know thy soul a product of the flesh,\nl
A made-up self in a constructed world.\nl
Thy words are large murmurs in a mystic dream.\nl
For how in the soiled heart of man could dwell\nl
The immaculate grandeur of thy dream-built God,\nl
Or who can see a face and form divine\nl
In the naked two-legged worm thou callest man?\nl
O human face, put off mind-painted masks:\nl
The animal be, the worm that Nature meant;\nl
Accept thy futile birth, thy narrow life.\nl
For truth is bare like stone and hard like death;\nl
Bare in the bareness, hard with truth's hardness live.”\nl
But Savitri replied to the dire God:\nl
“Yes, I am human. Yet shall man by me,\nl
Since in humanity waits his hour the God,\nl
Trample thee down to reach the immortal heights,\nl
Transcending grief and pain and fate and death.\nl
Yes, my humanity is a mask of God:\nl
He dwells in me, the mover of my acts,\nl
Turning the great wheel of his cosmic work.\nl
I am the living body of his light,\nl
I am the thinking instrument of his power,\nl
I incarnate Wisdom in an earthly breast,\nl
I am his conquering and unslayable will.\nl
The formless Spirit drew in me its shape;\nl
In me are the Nameless and the secret Name.”\nl
Page 634

Death from the incredulous Darkness sent its cry:\nl
“O priestess in Imagination's house,\nl
Persuade first Nature's fixed immutable laws\nl
And make the impossible thy daily work.\nl
How canst thou force to wed two eternal foes?\nl
Irreconcilable in their embrace\nl
They cancel the glory of their pure extremes:\nl
An unhappy wedlock maims their stunted force.\nl
How shall thy will make one the true and false?\nl
Where Matter is all, there Spirit is a dream:\nl
If all are the Spirit, Matter is a lie,\nl
And who was the liar who forged the universe?\nl
The Real with the unreal cannot mate.\nl
He who would turn to God, must leave the world;\nl
He who would live in the Spirit, must give up life;\nl
He who has met the Self, renounces self.\nl
The voyagers of the million routes of mind\nl
Who have travelled through Existence to its end,\nl
Sages exploring the world-ocean's vasts,\nl
Have found extinction the sole harbour safe.\nl
Two only are the doors of man's escape,\nl
Death of his body Matter's gate to peace,\nl
Death of his soul his last felicity.\nl
In me all take refuge, for I, Death, am God.”\nl
But Savitri replied to mighty Death:\nl
“My heart is wiser than the Reason's thoughts,\nl
My heart is stronger than thy bonds, O Death.\nl
It sees and feels the one Heart beat in all,\nl
It feels the high Transcendent's sunlike hands,\nl
It sees the cosmic Spirit at its work;\nl
In the dim Night it lies alone with God.\nl
My heart's strength can carry the grief of the universe\nl
And never falter from its luminous track,\nl
Its white tremendous orbit through God's peace.\nl
It can drink up the sea of All-Delight\nl
And never lose the white spiritual touch,\nl
Page 635

The calm that broods in the deep Infinite.”\nl
He said, “Art thou indeed so strong, O heart,\nl
O soul, so free? And canst thou gather then\nl
Bright pleasure from my wayside flowering boughs,\nl
Yet falter not from thy hard journey's goal,\nl
Meet the world's dangerous touch and never fall?\nl
Show me thy strength and freedom from my laws.”\nl
But Savitri answered, “Surely I shall find\nl
Among the green and whispering woods of Life\nl
Close-bosomed pleasures, only mine since his,\nl
Or mine for him, because our joys are one.\nl
And if I linger, Time is ours and God's,\nl
And if I fall, is not his hand near mine?\nl
All is a single plan; each wayside act\nl
Deepens the soul's response, brings nearer the goal.”\nl
Death the contemptuous Nihil answered her:\nl
“So prove thy absolute force to the wise gods,\nl
By choosing earthly joy! For self demand\nl
And yet from self and its gross masks live free.\nl
Then will I give thee all thy soul desires,\nl
All the brief joys earth keeps for mortal hearts.\nl
Only the one dearest wish that outweighs all,\nl
Hard laws forbid and thy ironic fate.\nl
My will once wrought remains unchanged through Time,\nl
And Satyavan can never again be thine.”\nl
But Savitri replied to the vague Power:\nl
“If the eyes of Darkness can look straight at Truth,\nl
Look in my heart and, knowing what I am,\nl
Give what thou wilt or what thou must, O Death.\nl
Nothing I claim but Satyavan alone.”\nl
There was a hush as if of doubtful fates.\nl
As one disdainful still who yields a point\nl
Death bowed his sovereign head in cold assent:\nl
“I give to thee, saved from death and poignant fate\nl
Whatever once the living Satyavan\nl
Desired in his heart for Savitri.\nl
Page 636

Bright noons I give thee and unwounded dawns,\nl
Daughters of thy own shape in heart and mind,\nl
Fair hero sons and sweetness undisturbed\nl
Of union with thy husband dear and true.\nl
And thou shalt harvest in thy joyful house\nl
Felicity of thy surrounded eves.\nl
Love shall bind by thee many gathered hearts.\nl
The opposite sweetness in thy days shall meet\nl
Of tender service to thy life's desired\nl
And loving empire over all thy loved,\nl
Two poles of bliss made one, O Savitri.\nl
Return, O child, to thy forsaken earth.”\nl
But Savitri replied, “Thy gifts resist.\nl
Earth cannot flower if lonely I return.”\nl
Then Death sent forth once more his angry cry,\nl
As chides a lion his escaping prey:\nl
“What knowst thou of earth's rich and changing life\nl
Who thinkst that one man dead all joy must cease?\nl
Hope not to be unhappy till the end:\nl
For grief dies soon in the tired human heart;\nl
Soon other guests the empty chambers fill.\nl
A transient painting on a holiday's floor\nl
Traced for a moment's beauty love was made.\nl
Or if a voyager on the eternal trail,\nl
Its objects fluent change in its embrace\nl
Like waves to a swimmer upon infinite seas.”\nl
But Savitri replied to the vague god,\nl
“Give me back Satyavan, my only lord.\nl
Thy thoughts are vacant to my soul that feels\nl
The deep eternal truth in transient things.”\nl
Death answered her, “Return and try thy soul!\nl
Soon shalt thou find appeased that other men\nl
On lavish earth have beauty, strength and truth,\nl
And when thou hast half forgotten, one of these\nl
Shall wind himself around thy heart that needs\nl
Some human answering heart against thy breast;\nl
Page 637

For who, being mortal, can dwell glad alone?\nl
Then Satyavan shall glide into the past,\nl
A gentle memory pushed away from thee\nl
By new love and thy children's tender hands,\nl
Till thou shalt wonder if thou lov'dst at all.\nl
Such is the life earth's travail has conceived,\nl
A constant stream that never is the same.”\nl
But Savitri replied to mighty Death:\nl
“O dark ironic critic of God's work,\nl
Thou mockst the mind and body's faltering search\nl
For what the heart holds in a prophet hour\nl
And the immortal spirit shall make its own.\nl
Mine is a heart that worshipped, though forsaken,\nl
The image of the god its love adored;\nl
I have burned in flame to travel in his steps.\nl
Are we not they who bore vast solitude\nl
Seated upon the hills alone with God?\nl
Why dost thou vainly strive with me, O Death,\nl
A mind delivered from all twilight thoughts,\nl
To whom the secrets of the gods are plain?\nl
For now at last I know beyond all doubt,\nl
The great stars burn with my unceasing fire\nl
And life and death are both its fuel made.\nl
Life only was my blind attempt to love:\nl
Earth saw my struggle, heaven my victory;\nl
All shall be seized, transcended; there shall kiss\nl
Casting their veils before the marriage fire\nl
The eternal bridegroom and eternal bride.\nl
The heavens accept our broken flights at last.\nl
On our life's prow that breaks the waves of Time\nl
No signal light of hope has gleamed in vain.”\nl
She spoke; the boundless members of the god\nl
As if by secret ecstasy assailed,\nl
Shuddered in silence as obscurely stir\nl
Ocean's dim fields delivered to the moon.\nl
Then lifted up as by a sudden wind\nl
Page 638

Around her in that vague and glimmering world\nl
The twilight trembled like a bursting veil.\nl
\sparn Thus with armed speech the great opponents strove.\nl
Around those spirits in the glittering mist\nl
A deepening half-light fled with pearly wings\nl
As if to reach some far ideal Morn.\nl
Outlined her thoughts flew through the gleaming haze\nl
Mingling bright-pinioned with its lights and veils\nl
And all her words like dazzling jewels were caught\nl
Into the glow of a mysterious world,\nl
Or tricked in the rainbow shifting of its hues\nl
Like echoes swam fainting into far sound.\nl
All utterance, all mood must there become\nl
An unenduring tissue sewn by mind\nl
To make a gossamer robe of beautiful change.\nl
Intent upon her silent will she walked\nl
On the dim grass of vague unreal plains,\nl
A floating veil of visions in her front,\nl
A trailing robe of dreams behind her feet.\nl
But now her spirit's flame of conscient force\nl
Retiring from a sweetness without fruit\nl
Called back her thoughts from speech to sit within\nl
In a deep room in meditation's house.\nl
For only there could dwell the soul's firm truth:\nl
Imperishable, a tongue of sacrifice,\nl
It flamed unquenched upon the central hearth\nl
Where burns for the high houselord and his mate\nl
The homestead's sentinel and witness fire\nl
From which the altars of the gods are lit.\nl
All still compelled went gliding on unchanged,\nl
Still was the order of these worlds reversed:\nl
The mortal led, the god and spirit obeyed\nl
And she behind was leader of their march\nl
And they in front were followers of her will.\nl
Onward they journeyed through the drifting ways\nl
Vaguely companioned by the glimmering mists.\nl
Page 639

But faster now all fled as if perturbed\nl
Escaping from the clearness of her soul.\nl
A heaven-bird upon jewelled wings of wind\nl
Borne like a coloured and embosomed fire,\nl
By spirits carried in a pearl-hued cave,\nl
On through the enchanted dimness moved her soul.\nl
Death walked in front of her and Satyavan,\nl
In the dark front of Death, a failing star.\nl
Above was the unseen balance of his fate.\nl
\rl{\fsc End of Canto Three}
Page 640

\par
\ht Canto Four: The Dream Twilight of the Earthly Real
\par
\sbigcap There came a slope that slowly downward sank;\nl
It slipped towards a stumbling grey descent.\nl
The dim-heart marvel of the ideal was lost;\nl
Its crowding wonder of bright delicate dreams\nl
And vague half-limned sublimities she had left:\nl
Thought fell towards lower levels; hard and tense\nl
It passioned for some crude reality.\nl
The twilight floated still but changed its hues\nl
And heavily swathed a less delightful dream;\nl
It settled in tired masses on the air;\nl
Its symbol colours tuned with duller reds\nl
And almost seemed a lurid mist of day.\nl
A straining taut and dire besieged her heart;\nl
Heavy her sense grew with a dangerous load,\nl
And sadder, greater sounds were in her ears,\nl
And through stern breakings of the lambent glare\nl
Her vision caught a hurry of driving plains\nl
And cloudy mountains and wide tawny streams,\nl
And cities climbed in minarets and towers\nl
Towards an unavailing changeless sky:\nl
Long quays and ghauts and harbours white with sails\nl
Challenged her sight awhile and then were gone.\nl
Amidst them travailed toiling multitudes\nl
In ever shifting perishable groups,\nl
A foiled cinema of lit shadowy shapes\nl
Enveloped in the grey mantle of a dream.\nl
Imagining meanings in life's heavy drift,\nl
They trusted in the uncertain environment\nl
And waited for death to change their spirit's scene.\nl
A savage din of labour and a tramp\nl
Of armoured life and the monotonous hum\nl
Page 641

Of thoughts and acts that ever were the same,\nl
As if the dull reiterated drone\nl
Of a great brute machine, beset her soul,—\nl
A grey dissatisfied rumour like a ghost\nl
Of the moaning of a loud unquiet sea.\nl
A huge inhuman cyclopean voice,\nl
A Babel-builders' song towering to heaven,\nl
A throb of engines and the clang of tools\nl
Brought the deep undertone of labour's pain.\nl
As when pale lightnings tear a tortured sky,\nl
High overhead a cloud-rimmed series flared\nl
Chasing like smoke from a red funnel driven,\nl
The forced creations of an ignorant Mind:\nl
Drifting she saw like pictured fragments flee\nl
Phantoms of human thought and baffled hopes,\nl
The shapes of Nature and the arts of man,\nl
Philosophies and disciplines and laws,\nl
And the dead spirit of old societies,\nl
Constructions of the Titan and the worm.\nl
As if lost remnants of forgotten light,\nl
Before her mind there fled with trailing wings\nl
Dimmed revelations and delivering words,\nl
Emptied of their mission and their strength to save,\nl
The messages of the evangelist gods,\nl
Voices of prophets, scripts of vanishing creeds.\nl
Each in its hour eternal claimed went by:\nl
Ideals, systems, sciences, poems, crafts\nl
Tireless there perished and again recurred,\nl
Sought restlessly by some creative Power;\nl
But all were dreams crossing an empty vast.\nl
Ascetic voices called of lonely seers\nl
On mountain summits or by river banks\nl
Or from the desolate heart of forest glades\nl
Seeking heaven's rest or the spirit's worldless peace,\nl
Or in bodies motionless like statues, fixed\nl
In tranced cessations of their sleepless thought\nl
Page 642

Sat sleeping souls, and this too was a dream.\nl
All things the past has made and slain were there,\nl
Its lost forgotten forms that once had lived,\nl
And all the present loves as new-revealed\nl
And all the hopes the future brings had failed\nl
Already, caught and spent in efforts vain,\nl
Repeated fruitlessly age after age.\nl
Unwearied all returned insisting still\nl
Because of joy in the anguish of pursuit\nl
And joy to labour and to win and lose\nl
And joy to create and keep and joy to kill.\nl
The rolling cycles passed and came again,\nl
Brought the same toils and the same barren end,\nl
Forms ever new and ever old, the long\nl
Appalling revolutions of the world.\nl

\spar Once more arose the great destroying Voice:\nl
Across the fruitless labour of the worlds\nl
His huge denial's all-defeating might\nl
Pursued the ignorant march of dolorous Time.\nl
“Behold the figures of this symbol realm,\nl
Its solid outlines of creative dream\nl
Inspiring the great concrete tasks of earth.\nl
In its motion-parable of human life\nl
Here thou canst trace the outcome Nature gives\nl
To the sin of being and the error in things\nl
And the desire that compels to live\nl
And man's incurable malady of hope.\nl
In an immutable order's hierarchy\nl
Where Nature changes not, man cannot change:\nl
Ever he obeys her fixed mutation's law;\nl
In a new version of her oft-told tale\nl
In ever-wheeling cycles turns the race.\nl
His mind is pent in circling boundaries:\nl
For mind is man, beyond thought he cannot soar.\nl
If he could leave his limits he would be safe:\nl
Page 643

He sees but cannot mount to his greater heavens;\nl
Even winged, he sinks back to his native soil.\nl
He is a captive in his net of mind\nl
And beats soul-wings against the walls of life.\nl
In vain his heart lifts up its yearning prayer,\nl
Peopling with brilliant Gods the formless Void;\nl
Then disappointed to the Void he turns\nl
And in its happy nothingness asks release,\nl
The calm Nirvana of his dream of self:\nl
The Word in silence ends, in Nought the name.\nl
Apart amid the mortal multitudes,\nl
He calls the Godhead incommunicable\nl
To be the lover of his lonely soul\nl
Or casts his spirit into its void embrace.\nl
Or he finds his copy in the impartial All;\nl
He imparts to the Immobile his own will,\nl
Attributes to the Eternal wrath and love\nl
And to the Ineffable lends a thousand names.\nl
Hope not to call God down into his life.\nl
How shalt thou bring the Everlasting here?\nl
There is no house for him in hurrying Time.\nl
Vainly thou seekst in Matter's world an aim;\nl
No aim is there, only a will to be.\nl
All walk by Nature bound for ever the same.\nl
Look on these forms that stay awhile and pass,\nl
These lives that long and strive, then are no more,\nl
These structures that have no abiding truth,\nl
The saviour creeds that cannot save themselves,\nl
But perish in the strangling hands of the years,\nl
Discarded from man's thought, proved false by Time,\nl
Philosophies that strip all problems bare\nl
But nothing ever have solved since earth began,\nl
And sciences omnipotent in vain\nl
By which men learn of what the suns are made,\nl
Transform all forms to serve their outward needs,\nl
Ride through the sky and sail beneath the sea,\nl
Page 644

But learn not what they are or why they came;\nl
These polities, architectures of man's brain,\nl
That, bricked with evil and good, wall in man's spirit\nl
And, fissured houses, palace at once and jail,\nl
Rot while they reign and crumble before they crash;\nl
These revolutions, demon or drunken god,\nl
Convulsing the wounded body of mankind\nl
Only to paint in new colours an old face;\nl
These wars, carnage triumphant, ruin gone mad,\nl
The work of centuries vanishing in an hour,\nl
The blood of the vanquished and the victor's crown\nl
Which men to be born must pay for with their pain,\nl
The hero's face divine on satyr's limbs,\nl
The demon's grandeur mixed with the demigod's,\nl
The glory and the beasthood and the shame;\nl
Why is it all, the labour and the din,\nl
The transient joys, the timeless sea of tears,\nl
The longing and the hoping and the cry,\nl
The battle and the victory and the fall,\nl
The aimless journey that can never pause,\nl
The waking toil, the incoherent sleep,\nl
Song, shouts and weeping, wisdom and idle words,\nl
The laughter of men, the irony of the gods?\nl
Where leads the march, whither the pilgrimage?\nl
Who keeps the map of the route or planned each stage?\nl
Or else self-moved the world walks its own way,\nl
Or nothing is there but only a Mind that dreams:\nl
The world is a myth that happened to come true,\nl
A legend told to itself by conscious Mind,\nl
Imaged and played on a feigned Matter's ground\nl
On which it stands in an unsubstantial Vast.\nl
Mind is the author, spectator, actor, stage:\nl
Mind only is and what it thinks is seen.\nl
If Mind is all, renounce the hope of bliss;\nl
If Mind is all, renounce the hope of Truth.\nl
For Mind can never touch the body of Truth\nl
Page 645

And Mind can never see the soul of God;\nl
Only his shadow it grasps nor hears his laugh\nl
As it turns from him to the vain seeming of things.\nl
Mind is a tissue woven of light and shade\nl
Where right and wrong have sewn their mingled parts;\nl
Or Mind is Nature's marriage of convenance\nl
Between truth and falsehood, between joy and pain:\nl
This struggling pair no court can separate.\nl
Each thought is a gold coin with bright alloy\nl
And error and truth are its obverse and reverse:\nl
This is the imperial mintage of the brain\nl
And of this kind is all its currency.\nl
Think not to plant on earth the living Truth\nl
Or make of Matter's world the home of God;\nl
Truth comes not there but only the thought of Truth,\nl
God is not there but only the name of God.\nl
If Self there is it is bodiless and unborn;\nl
It is no one and it is possessed by none.\nl
On what shalt thou then build thy happy world?\nl
Cast off thy life and mind, then art thou Self,\nl
An all-seeing omnipresence stark, alone.\nl
If God there is he cares not for the world;\nl
All things he sees with calm indifferent gaze,\nl
He has doomed all hearts to sorrow and desire,\nl
He has bound all life with his implacable laws;\nl
He answers not the ignorant voice of prayer.\nl
Eternal while the ages toil beneath,\nl
Unmoved, untouched by aught that he has made,\nl
He sees as minute details mid the stars\nl
The animal's agony and the fate of man:\nl
Immeasurably wise, he exceeds thy thought;\nl
His solitary joy needs not thy love.\nl
His truth in human thinking cannot dwell:\nl
If thou desirest Truth, then still thy mind\nl
For ever, slain by the dumb unseen Light.\nl
Immortal bliss lives not in human air:\nl
Page 646

How shall the mighty Mother her calm delight\nl
Keep fragrant in this narrow fragile vase,\nl
Or lodge her sweet unbroken ecstasy\nl
In hearts which earthly sorrow can assail\nl
And bodies careless Death can slay at will?\nl
Dream not to change the world that God has planned,\nl
Strive not to alter his eternal law.\nl
If heavens there are whose gates are shut to grief,\nl
There seek the joy thou couldst not find on earth;\nl
Or in the imperishable hemisphere\nl
Where Light is native and Delight is king\nl
And Spirit is the deathless ground of things,\nl
Choose thy high station, child of Eternity.\nl
If thou art Spirit and Nature is thy robe,\nl
Cast off thy garb and be thy naked self\nl
Immutable in its undying truth,\nl
Alone for ever in the mute Alone.\nl
Turn then to God, for him leave all behind;\nl
Forgetting love, forgetting Satyavan,\nl
Annul thyself in his immobile peace.\nl
O soul, drown in his still beatitude.\nl
For thou must die to thyself to reach God's height:\nl
I, Death, am the gate of immortality.”\nl
But Savitri answered to the sophist God:\nl
“Once more wilt thou call Light to blind Truth's eyes,\nl
Make Knowledge a catch of the snare of Ignorance\nl
And the Word a dart to slay my living soul?\nl
Offer, O King, thy boons to tired spirits\nl
And hearts that could not bear the wounds of Time,\nl
Let those who were tied to body and to mind,\nl
Tear off those bonds and flee into white calm\nl
Crying for a refuge from the play of God.\nl
Surely thy boons are great since thou art He!\nl
But how shall I seek rest in endless peace\nl
Who house the mighty Mother's violent force,\nl
Her vision turned to read the enigmaed world,\nl
Page 647

Her will tempered in the blaze of Wisdom's sun\nl
And the flaming silence of her heart of love?\nl
The world is a spiritual paradox\nl
Invented by a need in the Unseen,\nl
A poor translation to the creature's sense\nl
Of That which for ever exceeds idea and speech,\nl
A symbol of what can never be symbolised,\nl
A language mispronounced, misspelt, yet true.\nl
Its powers have come from the eternal heights\nl
And plunged into the inconscient dim Abyss\nl
And risen from it to do their marvellous work.\nl
The soul is a figure of the Unmanifest,\nl
The mind labours to think the Unthinkable,\nl
The life to call the Immortal into birth,\nl
The body to enshrine the Illimitable.\nl
The world is not cut off from Truth and God.\nl
In vain thou hast dug the dark unbridgeable gulf,\nl
In vain thou hast built the blind and doorless wall:\nl
Man's soul crosses through thee to Paradise,\nl
Heaven's sun forces its way through death and night;\nl
Its light is seen upon our being's verge.\nl
My mind is a torch lit from the eternal sun,\nl
My life a breath drawn by the immortal Guest,\nl
My mortal body is the Eternal's house.\nl
Already the torch becomes the undying ray,\nl
Already the life is the Immortal's force,\nl
The house grows of the householder part and one.\nl
How sayst thou Truth can never light the human mind\nl
And Bliss can never invade the mortal's heart\nl
Or God descend into the world he made?\nl
If in the meaningless Void creation rose,\nl
If from a bodiless Force Matter was born,\nl
If Life could climb in the unconscious tree,\nl
Its green delight break into emerald leaves\nl
And its laughter of beauty blossom in the flower,\nl
If sense could wake in tissue, nerve and cell\nl
Page 648

And Thought seize the grey matter of the brain,\nl
And soul peep from its secrecy through the flesh,\nl
How shall the nameless Light not leap on men,\nl
And unknown powers emerge from Nature's sleep?\nl
Even now hints of a luminous Truth like stars\nl
Arise in the mind-mooned splendour of Ignorance;\nl
Even now the deathless Lover's touch we feel:\nl
If the chamber's door is even a little ajar,\nl
What then can hinder God from stealing in\nl
Or who forbid his kiss on the sleeping soul?\nl
Already God is near, the Truth is close:\nl
Because the dark atheist body knows him not,\nl
Must the sage deny the Light, the seer his soul?\nl
I am not bound by thought or sense or shape;\nl
I live in the glory of the Infinite,\nl
I am near to the Nameless and Unknowable,\nl
The Ineffable is now my household mate.\nl
But standing on Eternity's luminous brink\nl
I have discovered that the world was He;\nl
I have met Spirit with spirit, Self with self,\nl
But I have loved too the body of my God.\nl
I have pursued him in his earthly form.\nl
A lonely freedom cannot satisfy\nl
A heart that has grown one with every heart:\nl
I am a deputy of the aspiring world,\nl
My spirit's liberty I ask for all.”\nl

\spar Then rang again a deeper cry of Death.\nl
As if beneath its weight of sterile law\nl
Oppressed by its own obstinate meaningless will,\nl
Disdainful, weary and compassionate,\nl
It kept no more its old intolerant sound,\nl
But seemed like life's in her unnumbered paths\nl
Toiling for ever and achieving nought\nl
Because of birth and change, her mortal powers\nl
By which she lasts, around the term-posts fixed\nl
Page 649

Turning of a wide circling aimless race\nl
Whose course for ever speeds and is the same.\nl
In its long play with Fate and Chance and Time\nl
Assured of the game's vanity lost or won,\nl
Crushed by its load of ignorance and doubt\nl
Which knowledge seems to increase and growth to enlarge,\nl
The earth-mind sinks and it despairs and looks\nl
Old, weary and discouraged on its work.\nl
Yet was all nothing then or vainly achieved?\nl
Some great thing has been done, some light, some power\nl
Delivered from the huge Inconscient's grasp:\nl
It has emerged from night; it sees its dawns\nl
Circling for ever though no dawn can stay.\nl
This change was in the godhead's far-flung voice;\nl
His form of dread was altered and admitted\nl
Our transient effort at eternity,\nl
Yet flung vast doubts of what might else have been\nl
On grandiose hints of an impossible day.\nl
The great voice surging cried to Savitri:\nl
“Because thou knowst the wisdom that transcends\nl
Both veil of forms and the contempt of forms,\nl
Arise delivered by the seeing gods.\nl
If free thou hadst kept thy mind from life's fierce stress,\nl
Thou mightst have been like them omniscient, calm.\nl
But the violent and passionate heart forbids.\nl
It is the storm bird of an anarch Power\nl
That would upheave the world and tear from it\nl
The indecipherable scroll of Fate,\nl
Death's rule and Law and the unknowable Will.\nl
Hasteners to action, violators of God\nl
Are these great spirits who have too much love,\nl
And they who formed like thee, for both art thou,\nl
Have come into the narrow bounds of life\nl
With too large natures overleaping time.\nl
Worshippers of force who know not her recoil,\nl
Their giant wills compel the troubled years.\nl
Page 650

The wise are tranquil; silent the great hills\nl
Rise ceaselessly towards their unreached sky,\nl
Seated on their unchanging base, their heads\nl
Dreamless in heaven's immutable domain.\nl
On their aspiring tops, sublime and still,\nl
Lifting half-way to heaven the climbing soul\nl
The mighty mediators stand content\nl
To watch the revolutions of the stars:\nl
Motionlessly moving with the might of earth,\nl
They see the ages pass and are the same.\nl
The wise think with the cycles, they hear the tread\nl
Of far-off things; patient, unmoved they keep\nl
Their dangerous wisdom in their depths restrained,\nl
Lest man's frail days into the unknown should sink\nl
Dragged like a ship by bound leviathan\nl
Into the abyss of his stupendous seas.\nl
Lo, how all shakes when the gods tread too near!\nl
All moves, is in peril, anguished, torn, upheaved.\nl
The hurrying aeons would stumble on too swift\nl
If strength from heaven surprised the imperfect earth\nl
And veilless knowledge smote these unfit souls.\nl
The deities have screened their dreadful power:\nl
God hides his thought and, even, he seems to err.\nl
Be still and tardy in the slow wise world.\nl
Mighty art thou with the dread goddess filled,\nl
To whom thou criedst at dawn in the dim woods.\nl
Use not thy strength like the wild Titan souls!\nl
Touch not the seated lines, the ancient laws,\nl
Respect the calm of great established things.”\nl
But Savitri replied to the huge god:\nl
“What is the calm thou vauntst, O Law, O Death?\nl
Is it not the dull-visioned tread inert\nl
Of monstrous energies chained in a stark round\nl
Soulless and stone-eyed with mechanic dreams?\nl
Vain the soul's hope if changeless Law is all:\nl
Ever to the new and the unknown press on\nl
Page 651

The speeding aeons justifying God.\nl
What were earth's ages if the grey restraint\nl
Were never broken and glories sprang not forth\nl
Bursting their obscure seed, while man's slow life\nl
Leaped hurried into sudden splendid paths\nl
By divine words and human gods revealed?\nl
Impose not upon sentient minds and hearts\nl
The dull fixity that binds inanimate things.\nl
Well is the unconscious rule for the animal breeds\nl
Content to live beneath the immutable yoke;\nl
Man turns to a nobler walk, a master path.\nl
I trample on thy law with living feet;\nl
For to arise in freedom I was born.\nl
If I am mighty let my force be unveiled\nl
Equal companion of the dateless powers,\nl
Or else let my frustrated soul sink down\nl
