\sect2
\par
\ht Epilogue: The Return to Earth
\par
\sbigcap Out of abysmal trance her spirit woke.\nl
Lain on the earth-mother's calm inconscient breast\nl
She saw the green-clad branches lean above\nl
Guarding her sleep with their enchanted life,\nl
And overhead a blue-winged ecstasy\nl
Fluttered from bough to bough with high-pitched call.\nl
Into the magic secrecy of the woods\nl
Peering through an emerald lattice-window of leaves,\nl
In indolent skies reclined, the thinning day\nl
Turned to its slow fall into evening's peace.\nl
She pressed the living body of Satyavan:\nl
On her body's wordless joy to be and breathe\nl
She bore the blissful burden of his head\nl
Between her breasts' warm labour of delight,\nl
The waking gladness of her members felt\nl
The weight of heaven in his limbs, a touch\nl
Summing the whole felicity of things,\nl
And all her life was conscious of his life\nl
And all her being rejoiced enfolding his.\nl
The immense remoteness of her trance had passed;\nl
Human she was once more, earth's Savitri,\nl
Yet felt in her illimitable change.\nl
A power dwelt in her soul too great for earth,\nl
A bliss lived in her heart too large for heaven;\nl
Light too intense for thought and love too boundless\nl
For earth's emotions lit her skies of mind\nl
And spread through her deep and happy seas of soul.\nl
All that is sacred in the world drew near\nl
To her divine passivity of mood.\nl
A marvellous voice of silence breathed its thoughts.\nl
All things in Time and Space she had taken for hers;\nl
Page 715

In her they moved, by her they lived and were,\nl
The whole wide world clung to her for delight,\nl
Created for her rapt embrace of love.\nl
Now in her spaceless self released from bounds\nl
Unnumbered years seemed moments long drawn out,\nl
The brilliant time-flakes of eternity.\nl
Outwingings of a bird from its bright home,\nl
Her earthly morns were radiant flights of joy.\nl
Boundless she was, a form of infinity.\nl
Absorbed no longer by the moment's beat\nl
Her spirit the unending future felt\nl
And lived with all the unbeginning past.\nl
Her life was a dawn's victorious opening,\nl
The past and unborn days had joined their dreams,\nl
Old vanished eves and far arriving noons\nl
Hinted to her a vision of prescient hours.\nl
Supine in musing bliss she lay awhile\nl
Given to the wonder of a waking trance;\nl
Half-risen then she sent her gaze around,\nl
As if to recover old sweet trivial threads,\nl
Old happy thoughts, small treasured memories,\nl
And weave them into one immortal day.\nl
Ever she held on the paradise of her breast\nl
Her lover charmed into a fathomless sleep,\nl
Lain like an infant spirit unaware\nl
Lulled on the verge of two consenting worlds.\nl
But soon she leaned down over her loved to call\nl
His mind back to her with her travelling touch\nl
On his closed eyelids; settled was her still look\nl
Of strong delight, not yearning now, but large\nl
With limitless joy or sovereign last content,\nl
Pure, passionate with the passion of the gods.\nl
Desire stirred not its wings; for all was made\nl
An overarching of celestial rays\nl
Like the absorbed control of sky on plain,\nl
Heaven's leaning down to embrace from all sides earth,\nl
Page 716

A quiet rapture, a vast security.\nl
Then sighing to her touch the soft-winged sleep\nl
Rose hovering from his flowerlike lids and flew\nl
Murmurous away. Awake, he found her eyes\nl
Waiting for his, and felt her hands, and saw\nl
The earth his home given back to him once more\nl
And her made his again, his passion's all.\nl
With his arms' encircling hold around her locked,\nl
A living knot to make possession close,\nl
He murmured with hesitating lips her name,\nl
And vaguely recollecting wonder cried,\nl
“Whence hast thou brought me captive back, love-chained,\nl
To thee and sunlight's walls, O golden beam\nl
And casket of all sweetness, Savitri,\nl
Godhead and woman, moonlight of my soul?\nl
For surely I have travelled in strange worlds\nl
By thee companioned, a pursuing spirit,\nl
Together we have disdained the gates of night.\nl
I have turned away from the celestials' joy\nl
And heaven's insufficient without thee.\nl
Where now has passed that formidable Shape\nl
Which rose against us, the Spirit of the Void,\nl
Claiming the world for Death and Nothingness,\nl
Denying God and soul? Or was all a dream\nl
Or a vision seen in a spiritual sleep,\nl
A symbol of the oppositions of Time\nl
Or a mind-lit beacon of significance\nl
In some stress of darkness lighting on the Way\nl
Or guiding a swimmer through the straits of Death,\nl
Or finding with the succour of its ray\nl
In a gully mid the crowded streets of Chance\nl
The soul that into the world-adventure came,\nl
A scout and voyager from Eternity?”\nl
But she replied, “Our parting was the dream;\nl
We are together, we live, O Satyavan.\nl
Look round thee and behold, glad and unchanged\nl
Page 717

Our home, this forest with its thousand cries\nl
And the whisper of the wind among the leaves\nl
And, through rifts in emerald scene, the evening sky,\nl
God's canopy of blue sheltering our lives,\nl
And the birds crying for heart's happiness,\nl
Winged poets of our solitary reign,\nl
Our friends on earth where we are king and queen.\nl
Only our souls have left Death's night behind,\nl
Changed by a mighty dream's reality,\nl
Illumined by the light of symbol worlds\nl
And the stupendous summit self of things,\nl
And stood at Godhead's gates limitless, free.”\nl
\sparn Then filled with the glory of their happiness\nl
They rose and with safe clinging fingers locked\nl
Hung on each other in a silent look.\nl
But he with a new wonder in his heart\nl
And a new flame of worship in his eyes:\nl
“What high change is in thee, O Savitri? Bright\nl
Ever thou wast, a goddess still and pure,\nl
Yet dearer to me by thy sweet human parts\nl
Earth gave thee making thee yet more divine.\nl
My adoration mastered, my desire\nl
Bent down to make its subject, my daring clasped,\nl
Claiming by body and soul my life's estate,\nl
Rapture's possession, love's sweet property,\nl
A statue of silence in my templed spirit,\nl
A yearning godhead and a golden bride.\nl
But now thou seemst almost too high and great\nl
For mortal worship; Time lies below thy feet\nl
And the whole world seems only a part of thee,\nl
Thy presence the hushed heaven I inhabit,\nl
And thou lookst on me in the gaze of the stars,\nl
Yet art the earthly keeper of my soul,\nl
My life a whisper of thy dreaming thoughts,\nl
My morns a gleaming of thy spirit's wings,\nl
And day and night are of thy beauty part.\nl
Page 718

Hast thou not taken my heart to treasure it\nl
In the secure environment of thy breast?\nl
Awakened from the silence and the sleep,\nl
I have consented for thy sake to be.\nl
By thee I have greatened my mortal arc of life,\nl
But now far heavens, unmapped infinitudes\nl
Thou hast brought me, thy illimitable gift!\nl
If to fill these thou lift thy sacred flight,\nl
My human earth will still demand thy bliss.\nl
Make still my life through thee a song of joy\nl
And all my silence wide and deep with thee.”\nl
A heavenly queen consenting to his will,\nl
She clasped his feet, by her enshrining hair\nl
Enveloped in a velvet cloak of love,\nl
And answered softly like a murmuring lute:\nl
“All now is changed, yet all is still the same.\nl
Lo, we have looked upon the face of God,\nl
Our life has opened with divinity.\nl
We have borne identity with the Supreme\nl
And known his meaning in our mortal lives.\nl
Our love has grown greater by that mighty touch\nl
And learned its heavenly significance,\nl
Yet nothing is lost of mortal love's delight.\nl
Heaven's touch fulfils but cancels not our earth:\nl
Our bodies need each other in the same last;\nl
Still in our breasts repeat heavenly secret rhythm\nl
Our human heart-beats passionately close.\nl
Still am I she who came to thee mid the murmur\nl
Of sunlit leaves upon this forest verge;\nl
I am the Madran, I am Savitri.\nl
All that I was before, I am to thee still,\nl
Close comrade of thy thoughts and hopes and toils,\nl
All happy contraries I would join for thee.\nl
All sweet relations marry in our life;\nl
I am thy kingdom even as thou art mine,\nl
The sovereign and the slave of thy desire,\nl
Page 719

Thy prone possessor, sister of thy soul\nl
And mother of thy wants; thou art my world,\nl
The earth I need, the heaven my thoughts desire,\nl
The world I inhabit and the god I adore.\nl
Thy body is my body's counterpart\nl
Whose every limb my answering limb desires,\nl
Whose heart is key to all my heart-beats,—this\nl
I am and thou to me, O Satyavan.\nl
Our wedded walk through life begins anew,\nl
No gladness lost, no depth of mortal joy.\nl
Let us go through this new world that is the same,\nl
For it is given back, but it is known,\nl
A playing-ground and dwelling-house of God\nl
Who hides himself in bird and beast and man\nl
Sweetly to find himself again by love,\nl
By oneness. His presence leads the rhythms of life\nl
That seek for mutual joy in spite of pain.\nl
We have each other found, O Satyavan,\nl
In the great light of the discovered soul.\nl
Let us go back, for eve is in the skies.\nl
Now grief is dead and serene bliss remains\nl
The heart of all our days for evermore.\nl
Lo, all these beings in this wonderful world!\nl
Let us give joy to all, for joy is ours.\nl
For not for ourselves alone our spirits came\nl
Out of the veil of the Unmanifest,\nl
Out of the deep immense Unknowable\nl
Upon the ignorant breast of dubious earth,\nl
Into the ways of labouring, seeking men,\nl
Two fires that burn towards that parent Sun,\nl
Two rays that travel to the original Light.\nl
To lead man's soul towards truth and God we are born,\nl
To draw the chequered scheme of mortal life\nl
Into some semblance of the Immortal's plan,\nl
To shape it closer to an image of God,\nl
A little nearer to the Idea divine.”\nl
Page 720

She closed her arms about his breast and head\nl
As if to keep him on her bosom worn\nl
For ever through the journeying of the years.\nl
So for a while they stood entwined, their kiss\nl
And passion-tranced embrace a meeting-point\nl
In their commingling spirits one for ever,\nl
Two-souled, two-bodied for the joys of Time.\nl
Then hand in hand they left that solemn place\nl
Full now of mute unusual memories,\nl
To the green distance of their sylvan home\nl
Returning slowly through the forest's heart.\nl
Round them the afternoon to evening changed;\nl
Light slipped down to the brightly sleeping verge,\nl
And the birds came back winging to their nests,\nl
And day and night leaned to each other's arms.\nl

\spar Now the dusk shadowy trees stood close around\nl
Like dreaming spirits and, delaying night,\nl
The grey-eyed pensive evening heard their steps,\nl
And from all points the cries and movements came\nl
Of the four-footed wanderers of the night\nl
Approaching. Then a human rumour rose\nl
Long alien to their solitary days,\nl
Invading the charmed wilderness of leaves\nl
Once sacred to secluded loneliness\nl
With violent breaking of its virgin sleep.\nl
Through the screened dusk it deepened still and there neared\nl
Floating of many voices and the sound\nl
Of many feet, till on their sight broke in\nl
As if a coloured wave upon the eye\nl
The brilliant strenuous crowded days of man.\nl
Topped by a flaring multitude of lights\nl
A great resplendent company arrived.\nl
Life in its ordered tumult wavering came\nl
Bringing its stream of unknown faces, thronged\nl
With gold-fringed headdresses, gold-broidered robes,\nl
Page 721

Glittering of ornaments, fluttering of hems,\nl
Hundreds of hands parted the forest-boughs,\nl
Hundreds of eyes searched the entangled glades.\nl
Calm white-clad priests their grave-eyed sweetness brought,\nl
Strong warriors in their glorious armour shone,\nl
The proud-hooved steeds came trampling through the wood.\nl
In front King Dyumatsena walked, no more\nl
Blind, faltering-limbed, but his far-questing eyes\nl
Restored to all their confidence in light\nl
Took seeingly this imaged outer world;\nl
Firmly he trod with monarch step the soil.\nl
By him that queen and mother's anxious face\nl
Came changed from its habitual burdened look\nl
Which in its drooping strength of tired toil\nl
Had borne the fallen life of those she loved.\nl
Her patient paleness wore a pensive glow\nl
Like evening's subdued gaze of gathered light\nl
Departing, which foresees sunrise her child.\nl
Sinking in quiet splendours of her sky,\nl
She lives awhile to muse upon that hope,\nl
The brilliance of her rich receding gleam\nl
A thoughtful prophecy of lyric dawn.\nl
Her eyes were first to find her children's forms.\nl
But at the vision of the beautiful twain\nl
The air awoke perturbed with scaling cries,\nl
And the swift parents hurrying to their child,—\nl
Their cause of life now who had given him breath,—\nl
Possessed him with their arms. Then tenderly\nl
Cried Dyumatsena chiding Satyavan:\nl
“The fortunate gods have looked on me today,\nl
A kingdom seeking came and heaven's rays.\nl
But where wast thou? Thou hast tormented gladness\nl
With fear's dull shadow, O my child, my life.\nl
What danger kept thee for the darkening woods?\nl
Or how could pleasure in her ways forget\nl
That useless orbs without thee are my eyes\nl
Page 722

Which only for thy sake rejoice at light?\nl
Not like thyself was this done, Savitri,\nl
Who ledst not back thy husband to our arms,\nl
Knowing with him beside me only is taste\nl
In food and for his touch evening and morn\nl
I live content with my remaining days.”\nl
But Satyavan replied with smiling lips,\nl
“Lay all on her; she is the cause of all.\nl
With her enchantments she has twined me round.\nl
Behold, at noon leaving this house of clay\nl
I wandered in far-off eternities,\nl
Yet still, a captive in her golden hands,\nl
I tread your little hillock called green earth\nl
And in the moments of your transient sun\nl
Live glad among the busy works of men.”\nl
Then all eyes turned their wondering looks where stood,\nl
A deepening redder gold upon her cheeks,\nl
With lowered lids the noble lovely child,\nl
And one consenting thought moved every breast.\nl
“What gleaming marvel of the earth or skies\nl
Stands silently by human Satyavan\nl
To mark a brilliance in the dusk of eve?\nl
If this is she of whom the world has heard,\nl
Wonder no more at any happy change.\nl
Each easy miracle of felicity\nl
Of her transmuting heart the alchemy is.”\nl
Then one spoke there who seemed a priest and sage:\nl
“O woman soul, what light, what power revealed,\nl
Working the rapid marvels of this day,\nl
Opens for us by thee a happier age?”\nl
Her lashes fluttering upwards gathered in\nl
To a vision which had scanned immortal things,\nl
Rejoicing, human forms for their delight.\nl
They claimed for their deep childlike motherhood\nl
The life of all these souls to be her life,\nl
Then falling veiled the light. Low she replied,\nl
Page 723

“Awakened to the meaning of my heart\nl
That to feel love and oneness is to live\nl
And this the magic of our golden change,\nl
Is all the truth I know or seek, O sage.”\nl
Wondering at her and her too luminous words\nl
Westward they turned in the fast-gathering night.\nl

\spar From the entangling verges freed they came\nl
Into a dimness of the sleeping earth\nl
And travelled through her faint and slumbering plains.\nl
Murmur and movement and the tread of men\nl
Broke the night's solitude; the neigh of steeds\nl
Rose from that indistinct and voiceful sea\nl
Of life and all along its marchings swelled\nl
The rhyme of hooves, the chariot's homeward voice.\nl
Drawn by white manes upon a high-roofed car\nl
In flare of the unsteady torches went\nl
With linked hands Satyavan and Savitri,\nl
Hearing a marriage march and nuptial hymn,\nl
Where waited them the many-voiced human world.\nl
Numberless the stars swam on their shadowy field\nl
Describing in the gloom the ways of light.\nl
Then while they skirted yet the southward verge,\nl
Lost in the halo of her musing brows\nl
Night, splendid with the moon dreaming in heaven\nl
In silver peace, possessed her luminous reign.\nl
She brooded through her stillness on a thought\nl
Deep-guarded by her mystic folds of light,\nl
And in her bosom nursed a greater dawn.\nl

\ht Note on the Text
Page 725

\preface
\par
\ht Note on the Text
\par\nodrop SAVITRI began as a narrative poem of moderate length based
on a legend told in the Mahabharata. Sri Aurobindo considered the story to be
originally “one of the many symbolic myths of the Vedic cycle”. Bringing out
its symbolism and charging it progressively with his own spiritual vision, he
turned {\it Savitri} into the epic it is today.
\par By the time it was published, some passages had gone through dozens of
drafts. Sri Aurobindo explained how he wrote the poem: “I used {\it Savitri}
as a means of ascension. I began with it on a certain mental level, each time
I could reach a higher level I rewrote from that level.\sdots In fact {\it
Savitri} has not been regarded by me as a poem to be written and finished,
but as a field of experimentation to see how far poetry could be written from
one's own yogic consciousness and how that could be made creative.”
\par The following outline of the composition and publication of {\it Savitri}
draws upon all existing manuscripts and other textual materials, supplemented
by the author's letters on the poem. In brief, {\it Savitri} took shape through
three major phases.
\par (1) Before 1920, Sri Aurobindo made a number of drafts of a narrative
poem retelling in an original way the tale of Savitri and Satyavan. Its last
version had a plan of eight books in two parts; the books were not divided
into cantos. (2) In the 1930s, he set about converting this narrative poem into
an epic. For a long time he concentrated on the description of Aswapati's
Yoga prior to the birth of Savitri, creating by 1945 a new Part One with three
books and many cantos. (3) In the last phase, besides revising Part One for
publication, he reworked and enlarged most of the books written in the first
period. He added a book on the Yoga of Savitri, making twelve books and
forty-nine cantos in all and completing Parts Two and Three.
\par
\ht The Composition of {\it Savitri}
\par Sri Aurobindo read the Savitri-episode of the Mahabharata in Sanskrit
while he was in Baroda. He expressed appreciation of its style in his “Notes
on the Mahabharata”, written around 1901. But a report that he worked on
an English poem on the subject at this time is not supported by his own
statements or any documents that survive. If there was a Baroda {\it Savitri},
which is doubtful, it was among the writings of which Sri Aurobindo wrote in
1933, “Most of all that has disappeared into the unknown in the whirlpools
and turmoil of my political career.” Even assuming that such a poem was
written in Baroda, for all practical purposes {\it Savitri} as we know it was
commenced in Pondicherry.
\par The opening of the first known version is dated “August 8th 9th / 1916”.
Further dates occur later on in the draft. From the death of Satyavan to the
end of Savitri's debate with Death, the manuscript is marked every few
pages with dates from a three-day period, 17-19 October. After this, the
consecutive narration breaks off and the notebook contains only disconnected
passages. Some of these are sketches for the conclusion of the poem. Most
of them go back over what was already written. They represent the
beginning of the long process of rewriting which was to continue until 1950.
\par This earliest surviving manuscript of {\it Savitri} shows every sign of
being the first draft. It is one of the few versions that Sri Aurobindo dated.
But even if precise dates cannot be assigned to them, the manuscripts of the
poem can almost always be placed in a definite order after a careful
comparison. This is because changes made when one draft was revised were
usually incorporated in the next draft, which would then be further altered
and most often expanded.
\par Initially the poem was short enough not to require division into books or
cantos. Its sections were separated only by blank lines. But soon Sri
Aurobindo was dividing it into “Book I”, ending with the death of Satyavan,
and “Book II”, recounting Savitri's debate with and victory over Death. Next
he adopted a scheme of six cantos and an epilogue. The canto titles were:
Love, Fate, Death, Night, Twilight and Day.
\par After making a few drafts in cantos, he started substituting the word
“book” for “canto”. There were now six books with the same names as the
former cantos. Meanwhile the larger division had reappeared as two parts,
“Earth” and “Beyond”. At first each part comprised three books, not
counting the epilogue. But before long, the rapidly growing first book was
broken up into two. The second book kept the name “Love”; the first was
renamed “Quest”.
\par A manuscript beginning with “Book I / Quest” has the title “S\^avithr\^i: A
Tale and a Vision”. (In early versions, “S\^avithr\^i” was the usual spelling of the
heroine's name.) Sri Aurobindo referred to this stage in the poem's history in
a letter of 1936: “{\it Savitri} was originally written many years ago before
the Mother came [{\it i.e., before the Mother's final arrival in 1920}], as a
narrative poem in two parts, Part I Earth and Part II Beyond\sdots each
of four books—or rather Part II consisted of three books and an epilogue.”
\par This was the plan of {\it Savitri} at the end of the first phase of its
composition. But the last manuscript actually completed was in six cantos and
an epilogue. After “books” replaced the “cantos” and the number of books
increased, some books were worked over several times. Others were hardly
touched. There is a partial draft of “Book III / Death”, for example; there is
none from the stage when “Death” would have been the fourth book. After
1945 when Sri Aurobindo incorporated material from the early poem into
what was by then a full-fledged epic, he sometimes went back to a
manuscript of the six “cantos” as his starting-point.
\par{\it Savitri} was apparently put aside during most of the 1920s, a period
when Sri Aurobindo did little writing. The first evidence of its resumption is
found in a letter of 1931. Here he speaks of a radical change in the
conception and scope of the poem. Already the subtitle, “A Legend and a
Symbol”, is present in his mind: “There is a previous draft, the result of the
many retouchings of which somebody told you; but in that form it would not
have been a `{\it magnum opus}' at all. Besides, it would have been a legend
and not a symbol. I therefore started recasting the whole thing; only the best
passages and lines of the old draft will remain, altered so as to fit into the
new frame.”
\par Throughout the thirties and early forties, it was primarily Book One that
was affected by this recasting. At first this book was still called “Quest”. It
extended as far as Savitri's arrival at “The Destined Meeting-Place” (the
eventual title of Book Five, Canto One). But in the early thirties, the brief
description of the Yoga of King Aswapati near the beginning swelled to
hundreds of lines. What was to become the second and longest book of the
epic, “The Book of the Traveller of the Worlds”, began to take shape.
\par In a letter of 1936, Sri Aurobindo mentioned a new first book, the “Book
of Birth”, carved out of the overgrown “Quest”. Another letter of the same
year reveals the internal structure of this book. It was “divided into sections
and the larger sections into subsections”. Up to this point, the books had been
divided only into passages separated by spaces, as many cantos are now. As
these sections increased in length, they were recognised as formal units and
began to be named and numbered. Section marks () were usually put before
and after the numbers.
\par The Book of Birth, whose last section related the birth and childhood of
Savitri, was still disproportionately long and was constantly growing. Early in
1937, Sri Aurobindo expressed his intention of rearranging the opening books
into a Book of Beginnings and a Book of Birth and Quest.
\par Progress on the poem was intermittent in the thirties due to Sri
Aurobindo's heavy load of correspondence. From the end of 1938 to
mid-1940, work on {\it Savitri} was suspended. But on 6 September 1942, a
110-page draft of the Book of Beginnings was completed. The fourth of its
eight sections, “The Ascent through the Worlds”, accounted for more than
half the total length and had twelve subsections. In the next version, this
section became Book Two with the title it now has. The last four sections
were grouped into Book Three, “The Book of the Divine Mother”.
\par The second phase in the composition of {\it Savitri} reached its
culmination when the first three books were written out in two columns on
large sheets. Many passages, including the whole of the first and third books
and much of the second, went through two or more drafts in this form. The
last complete manuscript is dated “May 7. 1944” at the end.
\par It was while revising this manuscript that Sri Aurobindo reintroduced the
word “canto” which he had not used since an early stage, applying it to the
former “sections” of the books. At this point the third section of Book One,
“The Yoga of the King”, was turned into Cantos 3-5 with their present titles.
The three opening books were for the first time identified as “Part One”.
\par The two-column manuscript is the last continuous version of Part One in
Sri Aurobindo's hand. But he went on reworking Book One and passages
throughout Book Two. For this purpose he began using small note-pads
whose sheets, containing new or rewritten matter, could be torn out and
pinned to the principal manuscript at the appropriate places.
\par By the mid-1940s, Sri Aurobindo's eyesight was failing and his
handwriting was becoming less and less legible. He needed the help of a
scribe in order to put Books 1-3 into a finished form, take up the
long-neglected later books, and prepare {\it Savitri} for publication. This third
phase of its composition saw periods of rapid and decisive progress. But it
was to be interrupted the month before Sri Aurobindo's passing, a little short
of definitive completion.
\par Much had still to be done with the first part. Sri Aurobindo asked the
scribe to read the last version to him. After dictating changes, insertions and
transpositions, he had his assistant copy it into a large ledger. This copy was
meticulously revised before being given to another disciple for typing. The
typescript in its turn was read out to Sri Aurobindo and similarly revised.
Heavily revised pages were often retyped. The same process was sometimes
repeated, especially in the later cantos of Book Two, where three typed
copies exist.
\par{\it Savitri} now began to appear in print, though not yet in its final form.
The first and third books were brought out canto by canto from August 1946
to February 1948 in journals connected with the Sri Aurobindo Ashram. They
were also published in fascicles identical to the journal instalments. The
second book was issued in 1947 and 1948 in two large fascicles.
\par Differences between the typescripts and the printed texts show that
proofs of the latter must have been revised in detail by Sri Aurobindo.
Afterwards a copy of each fascicle was read to him. Even at this advanced
stage, he made extensive alterations and added new lines and passages.
\par Meanwhile he had turned his attention to the later books. The plan of
Parts Two and Three resembled that of the pre-1920 poem, whose books had
been divided into “Earth” (Quest, Love, Fate, Death) and “Beyond” (Night,
Twilight, Day, Epilogue). By 1945, however, most of these books had
remained untouched for twenty-five years. Everything written under what Sri
Aurobindo termed in 1934 “the old insufficient inspiration” would have to be
thoroughly recast. Moreover, a new book had been conceived: The Book of
Yoga. Destined to become one of the longest in the epic, six of its seven
cantos were still to be drafted.
\par The material in the Book of Birth and Quest had for a long time been
included in Book One. As a result it had gone through several drafts in the
1930s, while other books lay dormant. The last book to be set aside, it was
also the first to be taken up again. One manuscript of it precedes the 1942
draft of the Book of Beginnings. The final version was evidently written
within a year or so of this. Since much work had already been done on it, this
book needed less modification than others. Yet especially in the first two
cantos, Sri Aurobindo dictated substantial changes and additions when he
revised the manuscript and typescript.
\par The Book of Love shared to some extent in the good fortune of the
previous book during the thirties and early forties. But the last version in Sri
Aurobindo's hand, in the notebook which starts with his final manuscript of
Book Four, breaks off in the middle of the second canto. The continuation is
in the scribe's hand. It was copied there probably two or three years later
when the systematic revision of the later books had been undertaken.
\par The remainder of this notebook contains the scribe's copy of Books Six,
Nine and Ten, reworked from the corresponding books in the old poem,
expanded, divided into cantos and renamed “The Book of Fate”, “The Book
of Eternal Night” and “The Book of the Double Twilight”. Once Sri
Aurobindo had done enough with Books Four and Five for the time being, it
appears that he took up these three books one after the other. After Book
Six, he skipped to Book Nine, postponing extensive work on Books Seven
and Eight. However, he may have revised slightly the versions of the original
third book or canto, “Death”, on which Book Seven, Canto One and the
present Book of Death are based.
\par Drafts of “Fate”, “Night” and “Twilight” had been written on one side of
loose sheets of paper, like other cantos or books in several early versions of
{\it Savitri}. This facilitated the complex process of revision which was now
set in motion. When the space between lines and in the margins was filled up,
the backs of the pages were available. In extreme cases, whole cantos were
written on the reverse sides of the pages with little relation to what was on
the front.
\par Sri Aurobindo drafted many passages in small note-pads of the type used
for Part One. Lines for Books Five and Nine and large portions of Books Six
and Ten were written in this way. Canto Two of Book Six was almost
entirely new. The passages drafted for it were transferred by the scribe to
another note-pad, with changes dictated by Sri Aurobindo at the time.
\par The metamorphosis which the Book of Fate underwent included the
introduction of the Queen: some of Aswapati's later speeches in the old
version were now given to her, and her long speech at the beginning of Canto
Two was composed. Sri Aurobindo worked on this book in 1946 and brought
it close to its final form. But he was to return to it at the end and add
significantly to the second canto.
\par An early manuscript of “Night” was substantially revised and turned into
the two cantos of Book Nine. But in this instance Sri Aurobindo seems to
have found the pre-1920 version more adequate than usual. He left it intact to
a greater extent than in the case of other books on which he bestowed his full
attention in the 1940s. Only the Book of Death and the Epilogue stayed
closer to their original shape, but he always intended to come back to these.
\par On the other hand, old drafts of “Twilight” formed merely a
starting-point for the four cantos of Book Ten. The speeches of Savitri and
Death were refashioned, rearranged in their order, and new ones inserted.
As he proceeded from one canto to the next, Sri Aurobindo added longer and
longer passages that were quite new. The first section of Canto One, the long
speech of Death which ends Canto Two, all but the last few pages of Canto
Three, and most of Canto Four—especially its second half, where Savitri
finally triumphs over Death—owe little or nothing to any early version.
\par In a letter of 22 April 1947, Sri Aurobindo summarised the status of the
various books of the second and third parts. Books Four, Five, Six, Nine and
Ten had by then “been completed, in a general way, with a sufficient finality
of the whole form but subject to final changes in detail”. The other four
books were far from even a provisional completion.
\par A “drastic recasting of the last two books” was felt to be needed and
“only a part of the eleventh” had been subjected to that process. But a yet
larger task lay ahead, the splitting up of the original Book of Death and the
writing of the new cantos that would go into the Book of Yoga. In his letter
of April 1947 Sri Aurobindo did not say what he planned to do next. But there
are reasons to believe that, rather than going on directly from Book Ten to
Book Eleven, he now retraced his steps to Book Seven.
\par The description of Savitri's Yoga, complementing that of Aswapati's
Yoga in Part One, was drafted in a thick notebook whose first hundred pages
are filled with drafts for Book Ten, Canto Four. By March 1947, even before
finishing the tenth book, Sri Aurobindo had begun to use this notebook for
preliminary work on Book Seven. The scribe was not asked to copy the
semi-legible handwriting of the draft. Instead, Sri Aurobindo dictated to him
the lines he had jotted down, often in a somewhat different form. The
dictated version was extensively revised before a typed copy was made.
\par The Book of Yoga had four cantos at first. But the second, “The
Parable of the Finding of the Soul”, grew to an inordinate length. When the
typescript was revised, it was broken up into Cantos 2-5, from “The Parable
of the Search for the Soul” to “The Finding of the Soul”. Revision of the
typed copy was so elaborate in places (as elsewhere, especially in Book Six,
Canto Two and in Book Eleven) that sometimes there was not enough room
on the page. The scribe would then write on separate slips of paper, attaching
as many as ten of these to a single page of the typescript.
\par Canto One of Book Seven has a different background. Early in the
evolution of {\it Savitri}, the third canto of the poem (later, the third book)
was called “Death”. It described the year leading up to Satyavan's death as
well as the fatal day itself. The latest version, with the heading “Book III”, is
incomplete and stops before the last day. Sri Aurobindo used this manuscript
as far as it goes when he put Book Seven, Canto One into its present form.
\par The second half of an earlier “Canto III” had to be used as the
manuscript for Book Eight. It was revised slightly near the beginning and a
substantial passage was dictated at the end. Sri Aurobindo apparently
intended to return to the Book of Death, but this was not to be.
\par On 20 July 1948 he was compelled to admit, “even {\it Savitri} has very
much slowed down and I am only making the last revisions of the First Part
already completed; the other two parts are just now in cold storage.” When
the later parts were taken up again, the most important task remaining was
evidently to bring the almost untouched eleventh book up to the level of what
preceded it. The old “Book VII / Day” on which it would be based was
among the best-developed portions of the early poem. But after thirty years,
Sri Aurobindo had more to say at the climax of {\it Savitri}.
\par There was also the Epilogue; but the contemplated revision of this must
have seemed less essential to the total design. Although a few pages of an
early version were significantly retouched at some stage, the concluding two
sections of the Epilogue stayed almost exactly as they were. Thus the closing
pages of the epic, like most of Book Eight, remained as a sample of the style
in which {\it Savitri} was originally written.
\par Near the end of his life, Sri Aurobindo's eyesight was so poor that he no
longer wrote at all. He made no more drafts for {\it Savitri} and the work
proceeded entirely by dictation. Virtually the whole revision of “The Book of
Everlasting Day” was done in this purely oral manner and may be inferred to
belong to this late period. There exist only a few pages of drafts for it in Sri
Aurobindo's hand, found in note-pads he used around 1946. He was probably
referring to these when he wrote in 1947 that he had already recast “part of
the eleventh” book.
\par Book Eleven culminates in the longest continuous dictated passage in {\it
Savitri}. The passage was written by the scribe in a separate note-pad and
seems to have no antecedent in any previous draft. This is the section which
begins on p. 702 with “Descend to life\sdots  ”, and ends at the bottom of
p. 710 with “This earthly life become the life divine.” Regarding Sri
Aurobindo's dictation in Book Eleven, the scribe reports that “line after line
began to flow from his lips like a smooth and gentle stream and it was on the
next day that a revision was done to get the link for further continuation.”
\par By this time, cantos of Parts Two and Three were coming out in journal
instalments and fascicles like those of Part One. Most of the cantos of Books
Four, Five, Six and Nine were published in this way in 1949-50. Unlike the
fascicles of the first part, they were not revised afterwards by Sri Aurobindo.
\par But in 1948, an extract from Book Six, Canto Two had already been
printed in the {\it Sri Aurobindo Mandir Annual}. An offprint of this was read
to Sri Aurobindo and the changes he dictated were incorporated in a retyped
copy. The painstaking revision of this second typescript was reportedly the
last work he did on {\it Savitri}. A short paragraph before the concluding
description of Narad's departure was the final passage to receive detailed
attention in November 1950, less than a month \NH before Sri Aurobindo's
passing. The thirteen-line paragraph was expanded to the seventy-two lines
beginning “Queen, strive no more to change the secret will.\sdots   ”
\par
\ht Editions of {\it Savitri}
\par Sri Aurobindo revised the proofs of the first edition of Part One, making
numerous final changes and adding more than a hundred new lines. In 1950,
Part One of {\it Savitri} appeared in book form. Parts Two and Three could
not be similarly revised. They came out in 1951 in a second volume, thus
completing the first edition.
\par The second edition was issued in 1954 in one volume under the imprint
of the Sri Aurobindo International University Centre. Some obvious errors in
the text of the first edition were emended at this time. A few of these were
evidently due to the mishearing of Sri Aurobindo's dictation.
\par In 1968, the first edition of Part One was reprinted with some new
textual corrections. The third complete edition (1970) contained further
emendations. Comprising Volumes 28 and 29 of the Sri Aurobindo Birth
Centenary Library, it was also brought out as a single volume in a reduced
format. This was reprinted a number of times between 1973 and 1990.
Several typographical and other errors were rectified in the 1976 impression.
\par The fourth, critically revised edition appeared in 1993. This edition was
the outcome of a systematic comparison of the printed text of {\it Savitri}
with the manuscripts. Each line was traced through all stages of copying,
typing and printing in which errors could have occurred. Readings found to
have come about through inaccurate transcription or misprinting were
corrected. Accidentally omitted lines were restored to the text. This has
resulted in a very slight increase in the length of the poem to its present
23,837 lines.
\par The 1993 edition has been reprinted several times. In 1997 it was
published as volumes 33 and 34 of the Complete Works of Sri Aurobindo.
\par The text of the present, electronic, edition (1999) is identical to the text
of the CWSA edition. As the page breaks in the CWSA edition are almost
everywhere identical to the page breaks in the SABCL edition, the SABCL
page numbers have not been given separately for this book.
